"I moved to Dresden in 2009 for my studies and kept coming back despite several stays abroad. I'm an artist, and this year I've had a hard time in this area. At first I thought it might completely miss me; I was just back from the release tour for my EP "Magnolia" when the first lockdown came. Two festivals were moved to 2021 during that time. We even received funding from Initiative Musik for my concert series at Katy's Garage, and I was fully occupied making up for cancelled concerts in the summer and organizing more. Then it hit me: other parts of Germany didn't yet have comparable easing of restrictions, and the release tour for my EP "Passionate" and a large part of the summer concerts were cancelled. From that point on, it was also difficult to book concerts, because nobody could or wanted to plan anymore. And it is still going on. I myself withdrew concerts in November and December partly because of the pandemic situation. So I could be creative this year, but I could not share it much. For me, this has financial implications for my self-employment until 2022.

But I don't want to complain. 2020 also gave me a lot of good things - for example, I had time to finish my distance learning as a digital music producer and to get into digital illustration. So I acquired new forms of expression and skills and also used and scheduled them for the implementation of first projects. Currently, for example, I have launched a crowdfunding campaign so that I can release a record recorded this year next year on CD and vinyl with my illustrations. Many of my most loyal listeners have already supported it. It runs until 15.01. If it succeeds, my album can be released in March despite the situation. That would make me very happy. I need to find new ways to continue to live and make a living from my passion, independent of playing live. This is my first crowdfunding effort. My first experiment of other forms of funding, so to speak. I am also already very overwhelmed and infinitely grateful for and touched by the participation and support I am getting.
Despite the difficulties, I will remain an artist, of course. The inner drive to do so does not disappear just because there are obstacles in the way. Of course, the challenges require flexibility and inventiveness. But in any case, I always come back to music. This activity fulfills me, there I can give the most, there everything falls into place. I also see it as a task as a human being to find something like that and to have the courage to live it. For me this is it.

For the future I hope that we are and stay healthy. I hope that we can be with each other again and that the appreciation will have grown. I actually don't hope that - I am confident that this will be the case. Maybe not yet in 2021, there's a time for everything. Thanks to all of you out there who are helping us get through this difficult time and to all of you who are playing by the rules and keeping your contacts to a minimum. Thank you. Together we can do this."

"The world is complex. But many today try to make it simple, so that they have something to fight for. Fighting, however, gets us nowhere. Fighting divides - even if it is for a supposedly good cause.

In recent years, many people have argued very emotionally and believe they have to fight for the right side. Pegida thinks they have to fight the Islamization of the Occident because otherwise Germany will go under, and the "multicolor" society thinks they have to fight Pegida because otherwise Germany will go under. This division has become so emotional that people no longer want to listen to the other side. This then leads to people only believing what fits into their own worldview. The facts of the other side are ignored and the other side is either simply a "stupid Nazi" or is part of the fake news. Depending on which side you are on.

I firmly believe that a society like ours only functions through cohesion - and that requires listening, even if it is difficult. We live in a country that values individual freedom above all else, and that's an enormous challenge. A system that wants to do justice to eighty million very different particular interests has to be complex and cleverly thought out. That's what our system is. But that complexity overwhelms many. That's why I made a few videos at the beginning of March to convey the basics of our society and our system, and thus to create more understanding for one another again: https://youtu.be/Nm5Hz6iDrBk

I always try to understand what is going on with other people. Especially in those that I myself can't or don't want to understand at first glance. I myself believe that the right to asylum is a basic human right. I also believe that a multicultural society enriches us, and stories like Ugur Sahin's touch me and confirm me in this image. But I also try to understand why people take to the streets on Mondays. I have seen and experienced myself (in Hamburg in the past and in Dresden today) that the street scene has changed, and I have also taken the trouble to look at figures on this.

I have summarized the results here: https://www.facebook.com/FerdinandSaalbach/posts/471063860950005.

The very central core statement there is that we have a significant and clearly visible problem with criminality by foreigners since 2015. That is why it is wrong to accuse people at Pegida of seeing the world in a distorted way. But it is very important for me to say about this that simply is the factual situation. It is not a political statement and it is certainly not a justification for hatred.

It is important to me that we talk about "real" facts and not about processed facts. Pegida, but also the "colorful" side, often twist the numbers to suit their world view. That's why I made the contribution about the BKA figures -- to really just take completely naked raw data, without any calculation. I simply present what is, in order to provide a basis for genuinely fact-based debate - and I show every single step I have taken in a comprehensible way. I'm also happy to talk about it with anyone who has questions about it. But factually. I studied statistics for several semesters and, in particular, taught how to prepare and communicate data for eight years at a university. I know how to twist numbers to make them fit your message. But that's exactly why I want to show that anyone can access the bare basic data to see how the world really is. No one needs to be a statistician to do this. He should only be able to read a table - but as usual in science: without wanting to have his own message confirmed, but with curiosity and openness and the willingness to question his own world view.

I believe that the current divide mainly benefits business and the established parties. That's why some media are pushing it. Then they like to show the idiot at Pegida on TV so that the " colorful " at home can rise above him and feel vindicated in the fact that there are just idiots running around anyway. Because when people argue about the AfD, they have less time to look at the evil misdeeds of the CDU in the last year(s). Things have really gone off the rails here. But as long as we are busy fighting each other, we lose sight of what is really important. And in the end, that only benefits those who profit from it. In this video I have approached this a little bit:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xyun2hCQPZ0.

These mechanisms have created mistrust in politics and also mistrust in our fellow human beings. This hits us now with the coronavirus with full force. Because the distrust in the ruling politics, which has been nurtured for decades, is now causing us enormous problems, because some do not want to and can no longer believe the government and are boycotting vital measures out of defiance.

The Corona pandemic showed me how fragile our democracy is. It can only survive if we all understand why living together in a democratic and free state is complex. Both sides currently have deficits in this area. On both sides, I see the desire to keep the other side small and muzzled, or even to eradicate it. These thoughts are the breeding ground for fascism. And fascism does not care from which political direction it arises.

Fascism is always when one part of people elevates itself above another and tries to make it go away. That is always wrong, and that must not happen in a democracy. That's why we have a very sophisticated system that guarantees everyone their voice and their representation in the legislative process. This system is complex, it is unique in the world in this form, and for me it is the best system I have had the pleasure of knowing. We should learn to value this system and each other more again. That is what I am working for. With videos, with conversations, with contributions and - just like this page - with listening. Because only those who listen with an open heart and an open ear, even to people whose opinions they disagree with, and do so with the goal of really wanting to understand them and not to instruct them, really learn something about the world."

"The world is complex. But many today try to make it simple, so that they have something to fight for. Fighting, however, gets us nowhere. Fighting divides - even if it is for a supposedly good cause.

This division has become so emotional that people no longer want to listen to the other side. This then leads to people only believing what fits into their own worldview. The facts of the other side are ignored and the other side is either simply a "stupid Nazi" or is part of the fake news. Depending on which side you are on.

I firmly believe that a society like ours only functions through cohesion - and that requires listening, even if it is difficult. We live in a country that values individual freedom above all else, and that's an enormous challenge. That's why I made a few videos at the beginning of March to convey the basics of our society and our system, and thus to create more understanding for one another again: https://youtu.be/Nm5Hz6iDrBk

I myself believe that the right to asylum is a basic human right. I also believe that a multicultural society enriches us, and stories like Ugur Sahin's touch me and confirm me in this image. But I also try to understand why people take to the streets on Mondays. I have seen and experienced myself (in Hamburg in the past and in Dresden today) that the street scene has changed, and I have also taken the trouble to look at figures on this.

I have summarized the results here: https://www.facebook.com/FerdinandSaalbach/posts/471063860950005.

That is why it is wrong to accuse people at Pegida of seeing the world in a distorted way. But it is very important for me to say about this that simply is the factual situation. It is not a political statement and it is certainly not a justification for hatred.

It is important to me that we talk about "real" facts and not about processed facts. Pegida, but also the "colorful" side, often twist the numbers to suit their world view. That's why I made the contribution about the BKA figures -- to really just take completely naked raw data, without any calculation. I simply present what is, in order to provide a basis for genuinely fact-based debate - and I show every single step I have taken in a comprehensible way. I'm also happy to talk about it with anyone who has questions about it. But factually. I studied statistics for several semesters and, in particular, taught how to prepare and communicate data for eight years at a university. I know how to twist numbers to make them fit your message. But that's exactly why I want to show that anyone can access the bare basic data to see how the world really is. No one needs to be a statistician to do this. He should only be able to read a table - but as usual in science: without wanting to have his own message confirmed, but with curiosity and openness and the willingness to question his own world view.

I believe that the current divide mainly benefits business and the established parties. That's why some media are pushing it. Then they like to show the idiot at Pegida on TV so that the " colorful " at home can rise above him and feel vindicated in the fact that there are just idiots running around anyway. Because when people argue about the AfD, they have less time to look at the evil misdeeds of the CDU in the last year(s). Things have really gone off the rails here. But as long as we are busy fighting each other, we lose sight of what is really important. And in the end, that only benefits those who profit from it. In this video I have approached this a little bit:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xyun2hCQPZ0.

These mechanisms have created mistrust in politics and also mistrust in our fellow human beings. This hits us now with the coronavirus with full force. Because the distrust in the ruling politics, which has been nurtured for decades, is now causing us enormous problems, because some do not want to and can no longer believe the government and are boycotting vital measures out of defiance.

The Corona pandemic showed me how fragile our democracy is. It can only survive if we all understand why living together in a democratic and free state is complex. Both sides currently have deficits in this area. On both sides, I see the desire to keep the other side small and muzzled, or even to eradicate it. These thoughts are the breeding ground for fascism. And fascism does not care from which political direction it arises.

Fascism is always when one part of people elevates itself above another and tries to make it go away. That is always wrong, and that must not happen in a democracy. That's why we have a very sophisticated system that guarantees everyone their voice and their representation in the legislative process. This system is complex, it is unique in the world in this form, and for me it is the best system I have had the pleasure of knowing. We should learn to value this system and each other more again. That is what I am working for. With videos, with conversations, with contributions and - just like this page - with listening. Because only those who listen with an open heart and an open ear, even to people whose opinions they disagree with, and do so with the goal of really wanting to understand them and not to instruct them, really learn something about the world."

"I have been working in the field of youth welfare for five years with an independent organization. Professionally, I now mainly help families as a family support worker, with a focus on migrant families, because this has always been a key issue for me. Even before the refugee crisis in 2015, I studied education in Bamberg with a focus on social pedagogy and family pedagogy and a minor in sociology. You could choose migration as a focus of the combination as well.

I have also been a volunteer guardian since 2016. As a volunteer guardian, I have the rights and responsibilities of a parent for a refugee who is here without his parents. Some people also have several wards; I've only had one.
I have always wanted to help people. A lot of the work at that time was focused on working with teenagers, especially in the social work field. However, I found families and my fellow citizens with a migration background to be more interesting. I already had a friend from Romania, and one from Azerbaijan when I was in school. Both talked about integration problems every now and then, not the "hard stuff" like racism, but just language difficulties and the desire for support. Then in 2012, I met my dear friend Aissulu, a native of Kazakhstan and a born Muslim. However, she left the religion because she finds much of how it is lived out today incompatible with its original values.

Now through Corona, there has been a big outcry from many parents about childcare. Many feel overworked, meaning beyond the normal "it's just exhausting". I write quite often under such posts " Contact the social welfare services, don't be afraid." Unfortunately, many see welfare services as the evil institution that takes children away, but there are also really many options for help, and taking them out is really only the very last step.

Right now, I feel like we're not being applauded enough. That's not to say that you need people to applaud, but that's what came up through Corona. There are many inpatient facilities in the youth welfare sector. The employees there also work 24 hours a day, which is naturally more strenuous thanks to Corona. But we are also there for the families on an outpatient basis, we provide a cushion when emergency care is not yet available or meeting places are closed. For many families who have structural problems due to mental illness, for example, a lot is lost. You can't imagine it like that. The structure breaks down, the affected parent is often overburdened, and the children get into more trouble, which then leads to stress. I go there and sometimes help in a very practical way, by helping with putting the children to bed, dealing with conflicts and maintaining a few fixed points to which one can hold on - for example, having lunch together or all cleaning up together. And I provide emergency care if that can also help relieve the pressure. I think we should be glad that something like the Youth Welfare Office exists here at all and that we can get support. Many of the families we care for don't have their own network to fall back on.

We always try to help the families to get along on their own again and link them to family centers, where open meetings take place - to exchange ideas, not to be alone - and now they are closed, which is very difficult. We do more hours accordingly, as needed, to support the families as well as possible. In the end, our work does, after all, relieve the clinics again. I really hope that I can take away people's fear of seeking help - rather preventively than when it might then be too late."

"I was born in Dresden in 1998 and spent the first 18 years of my life here. The city, but also its surroundings such as Saxon Switzerland, shaped my childhood. In 2016, I moved to Stuttgart to study - I wanted to leave my familiar surroundings and experience something new. Now I've been studying political science and history in Heidelberg. In my opinion, the city has many similarities to Dresden. It has a beautiful old city center, with lots of green spaces and meadows right by the river. That already brings a certain quality of life with it, which I appreciate very much. However, I miss a generous bike path and public transportation network in Heidelberg as in Dresden. Despite the current politically tense situation in Saxony, I'm drawn to Dresden on a regular basis, whether it's during the lecture-free period or for a family celebration. Sooner or later, I will return to Dresden completely. I still see my home here. I hope that by then a more open attitude and acceptance towards diversity and sustainability will have taken hold in my hometown. 

I am a politically interested and active person. When the Pegida demonstrations began in Dresden in 2015, I was part of the counter-demonstration for a while. For the past two years, I have been campaigning through Foodsharing and Rettenswert Heidelberg e.V. against food waste and for a more sustainable use of resources. Only through a shift in thinking in our society can more sustainable development and thus better living conditions for humans and animals be achieved. Everyone can make a personal contribution. To live my commitment myself, I eat vegetarian, go shopping in bulk stores and get around via public transport and bicycle. 

In Heidelberg, I notice a very different culture of citizen participation in local politics. Most recently, a citizens' petition was launched against the relocation of the arrival center for refugees. There will be a citizens' referendum on this in April. I would also like to see more direct participation in politics by and with citizens in Dresden. In Heidelberg, people also complain, but they actively participate in the political process. In Dresden, there is a lot of complaining, but nothing happens. 

I have the feeling that many people from the older generation feel neglected and unfairly treated by the process of reunification and therefore do not trust the current political system and do not become active themselves. Through my studies, I have studied the process of reunification a lot, and I am also of the opinion that a lot went wrong at that time and that it has a negative effect on the people in the former East Germany today. In my opinion, however, that in no way justifies this generally negative attitude toward politics and the sullenness that goes along with it.

In my opinion, politics has lost its connection to the populace. You have to show people that you are still on the same level - offer more citizens' consultation hours, implement local actions on the ground, engage with and support citizens' initiatives, etc. Especially in Dresden, local politics and the administration should involve the citizens much more in the development of the city: What is important to you? How do you imagine district XYZ in ten years? And talking in general would be important, approaching all citizens without prejudice. No matter where they are active or where they have been active in the past. One can and will never be able to please everyone. But by including everyone, a sense of community is created that Dresden currently lacks. In my opinion, only by including everyone can the gap between the two camps in Dresden, especially on the migration issue, be overcome. 

This is perhaps also a small thought-provoking idea for the new year: if you approach others and are open to other opinions, you can often achieve more through small steps in all areas of life than if you insist on your own point of view."

"The new year is beginning for me with unemployment. I was employed at the Dresden Umweltzentrum until 31.12.2020 in the management and public relations in the project "New Home Everyday" of the ABC tables. This work now continues completely on a voluntary basis until the new funding decision hopefully arrives soon and thus my contract and those of my colleagues can be continued. Most projects at the Umweltzentrum work this way, because the work with plants, animals and humans does not follow any logic of funding periods. Without volunteerism, no associations, that's an old equation.

Nevertheless, I hope that the funding will be continued soon, because the tables would change without their full-time staff. Our (almost) daily meeting (except on Mondays) could not be coordinated and run at this frequency with volunteers alone.

The ABC-Tables have been a constant for all "newcomers" in Dresden for 5 1/2 years. From Tuesday to Saturday, always from 2:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., they find Dresdeners who support them in their first steps in their new city, no matter whether it is about concrete homework help in language or integration courses or about the security of knowing that there are people there for them (almost) every day and support them in finding their way in their new home. It is about sharing everyday life, laughter and sorrow, and establishing a sense of security in dealing with each other through the regularity of the meetings and providing points of contact with one's own living environment that cannot be conveyed in this way in a language or integration course. For the volunteers from Dresden, it is a nice task to be able to help and at the same time gain insights into the worlds of Iran, Iraq, Syria, Afghanistan, Kenya, Chile, China or Ecuador.

I have been a Dresdener since 1998 and I think that with this project I am bringing a little bit of the world that I already traveled"into my living room." I studied and worked abroad and can therefore in principle well understand everyone who does the same thing or would like to have this opportunity in our country.

The nicest compliment is always when people tell me: "The tables, is our family here in Dresden." This description comes very close to how I feel. Family is neither 24/7 together, nor do we all live under one roof. Some members of our Table family have long since moved away from Dresden. However, as in any other family, contact does not necessarily break off. We seek each other out and share with each other, sometimes over distances as great as from Dresden to Adelaide in Australia or Ulan-Bator in Mongolia, or over a period as long as from August 2015 to today, January 6, 2021.
The feeling of wanting to know how the other person is doing at the moment also brings concern and personal suffering or compassion, sometimes a heaviness and dismay. The refugees among the table participants often still live in two worlds, here in Dresden and in thoughts and via video chat with their families in their countries of origin. Two realities of life that often could not be more unequal. These fates inevitably move me and many of our volunteer "original Dresdeners". One always thinks of the person in the Dresden here and now and at the same time as a lost son, lost daughter of their family at home.

I draw my motivation from the conviction that every city should be open for migrants, no matter if they come as refugees and ask for asylum or are people with study, internship or work visas. But whose task in a city should it be to welcome migrants and how concretely should this "welcome" be shaped? I think we have found a possible answer to this question with the ABC tables of the Dresden Umweltzentrum and "New Home Everyday".
On Mondays we are closed - like the museums - in whose atrium and cafeteria we meet, and otherwise we are there daily from 14:00 to 18:00 (online 15:00-18:00). Dependable and as a matter of course, but without being compulsory, neither on the part of the volunteers, nor with regard to the "newcomers in Dresden". We are responsive to any topic, in the knowledge that we can mostly only pass on and interpret, but not to take the responsibility for problem solving out of the hands of those who have to solve it for themselves. We present our interpretations of the German, the Dresden reality and are curious about the interpretations of those who have brought their life stories to Dresden. A welcome can hardly be more fundamental, more open, more unbiased. This motivates me and challenges me again and again.

At the moment, unfortunately, we are not meeting as usual in the Albertinum or in the Stadtmuseum, but we have opened up a virtual space where anyone can visit us, every Tuesday to Friday 3 p.m. - 6 p.m. at https://meet.jit.si/alltag-neue-heimat Without an app or registration! We warmly invite you."

Wir suchen einander und teilen uns einander mit, manchmal Ã¼ber so groÃe Distanzen hinweg wie von Dresden nach Adelaide in Australien oder Ulan-Bator in der Mongolei oder Ã¼ber einen so langen Zeitraum wie von August 2015 bis heute, den 6. Januar 2021.

Das GefÃ¼hl, wissen zu wollen, wie es dem, der anderen gerade geht, bringt auch Sorge und persÃ¶nliches Leid bzw. MitgefÃ¼hl, manchmal eine Schwere und Betroffenheit mit sich. Gerade die GeflÃ¼chteten unter den Tische-Teilnehmer*innen leben hÃ¤ufig und nach wie vor in zwei Welten, hier in Dresden und in Gedanken und per Videochat mit ihren Familien in ihren HerkunftslÃ¤ndern. Zwei Lebenswirklichkeiten, die hÃ¤ufig ungleicher nicht sein kÃ¶nnten. Diese Schicksale bewegen mich und viele unsere ehrenamtlichen "Urdresdner*innen" unweigerlich. Man denkt die Person immer im Dresdner Hier und Jetzt und gleichzeitig als verlorener Sohn, verlorene Tochter ihrer Heimatfamilie mit.

Meine Motivation schÃ¶pfe ich aus der Ãberzeugung, dass jede Stadt offen fÃ¼r Migrant*innen sein sollte, egal ob sie als GeflÃ¼chtete kommen und um Asyl bitten oder Menschen mit Studiums-, Praktikums- oder Arbeitsvisum sind. Aber wessen Aufgabe in einer Stadt sollte es sein, Migrant*innen willkommen zu heiÃen und wie konkret soll dieses "Willkommen" gestaltet werden? Eine mÃ¶gliche Antwort darauf haben wir, denke ich, mit den ABC-Tischen des Umweltzentrums Dresden und "Alltag Neue Heimat" gefunden.

Montags sind wir - wie die Museen - in deren Lichthof und Cafeteria wir uns treffen, geschlossen und ansonsten tÃ¤glich von 14:00 bis 18:00 Uhr (online 15:00-18:00 Uhr) da. VerlÃ¤sslich und selbstverstÃ¤ndlich, aber ohne Anspruch auf Anwesenheitspflicht, weder seitens der Ehrenamtlichen, noch im Hinblick auf die "Neuen in Dresden". Wir sind ansprechbar auf jedes Thema, im Wissen, meist nur weitervermitteln und interpretieren zu kÃ¶nnen, die Verantwortung aber fÃ¼r ProblemlÃ¶sungen nicht aus den HÃ¤nden derer zu nehmen, die sie fÃ¼r sich lÃ¶sen mÃ¼ssen. Wir legen unsere Interpretationen der deutschen, der Dresdner Wirklichkeit dar und sind neugierig auf die Interpretationen derer, die ihre Lebensgeschichte mit nach Dresden gebracht haben. GrundsÃ¤tzlicher, offener, unvoreingenommener kann ein Willkommen wohl kaum sein. Das motiviert mich und fordert mich immer aufs Neues heraus.

Momentan treffen wir uns leider nicht wie immer im Albertinum oder im Stadtmuseum, haben uns aber einen virtuellen Raum erschlossen, in dem uns jede und jeder besuchen kann, immer Dienstag bis Freitag 15.00 â 18.00 Uhr unter https://meet.jit.si/alltag-neue-heimat Ohne App und Anmeldung! Wir laden herzlich ein."

"The new year is beginning for me with unemployment. I was employed at the Dresden Umweltzentrum until 31.12.2020 in the management and public relations in the project "New Home Everyday" of the ABC tables. This work now continues completely on a voluntary basis until the new funding decision hopefully arrives soon and thus my contract and those of my colleagues can be continued. Most projects at the Umweltzentrum work this way, because the work with plants, animals and humans does not follow any logic of funding periods. Without volunteerism, no associations, that's an old equation.

Nevertheless, I hope that the funding will be continued soon, because the tables would change without their full-time staff. Our (almost) daily meeting (except on Mondays) could not be coordinated and run at this frequency with volunteers alone.

The ABC-Tables have been a constant for all "newcomers" in Dresden for 5 1/2 years. From Tuesday to Saturday, always from 2:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., they find Dresdeners who support them in their first steps in their new city, no matter whether it is about concrete homework help in language or integration courses or about the security of knowing that there are people there for them (almost) every day and support them in finding their way in their new home. It is about sharing everyday life, laughter and sorrow, and establishing a sense of security in dealing with each other through the regularity of the meetings and providing points of contact with one's own living environment that cannot be conveyed in this way in a language or integration course. For the volunteers from Dresden, it is a nice task to be able to help and at the same time gain insights into the worlds of Iran, Iraq, Syria, Afghanistan, Kenya, Chile, China or Ecuador.

I have been a Dresdener since 1998 and I think that with this project I am bringing a little bit of the world that I already traveled"into my living room." I studied and worked abroad and can therefore in principle well understand everyone who does the same thing or would like to have this opportunity in our country.

The nicest compliment is always when people tell me: "The tables, is our family here in Dresden." This description comes very close to how I feel. Family is neither 24/7 together, nor do we all live under one roof. Some members of our Table family have long since moved away from Dresden. However, as in any other family, contact does not necessarily break off. We seek each other out and share with each other, sometimes over distances as great as from Dresden to Adelaide in Australia or Ulan-Bator in Mongolia, or over a period as long as from August 2015 to today, January 6, 2021.
The feeling of wanting to know how the other person is doing at the moment also brings concern and personal suffering or compassion, sometimes a heaviness and dismay. The refugees among the table participants often still live in two worlds, here in Dresden and in thoughts and via video chat with their families in their countries of origin. Two realities of life that often could not be more unequal. These fates inevitably move me and many of our volunteer "original Dresdeners". One always thinks of the person in the Dresden here and now and at the same time as a lost son, lost daughter of their family at home.

I draw my motivation from the conviction that every city should be open for migrants, no matter if they come as refugees and ask for asylum or are people with study, internship or work visas. But whose task in a city should it be to welcome migrants and how concretely should this "welcome" be shaped? I think we have found a possible answer to this question with the ABC tables of the Dresden Umweltzentrum and "New Home Everyday".
On Mondays we are closed - like the museums - in whose atrium and cafeteria we meet, and otherwise we are there daily from 14:00 to 18:00 (online 15:00-18:00). Dependable and as a matter of course, but without being compulsory, neither on the part of the volunteers, nor with regard to the "newcomers in Dresden". We are responsive to any topic, in the knowledge that we can mostly only pass on and interpret, but not to take the responsibility for problem solving out of the hands of those who have to solve it for themselves. We present our interpretations of the German, the Dresden reality and are curious about the interpretations of those who have brought their life stories to Dresden. A welcome can hardly be more fundamental, more open, more unbiased. This motivates me and challenges me again and again.

At the moment, unfortunately, we are not meeting as usual in the Albertinum or in the Stadtmuseum, but we have opened up a virtual space where anyone can visit us, every Tuesday to Friday 3 p.m. - 6 p.m. at https://meet.jit.si/alltag-neue-heimat Without an app or registration! We warmly invite you."

Zwischen meinen Krallen wollte ich ihr Kopfkissen mitnehmen, aber das trug sie stur zurÃ¼ck in ihr Bett. Frechheit.

Stoisch blieb ich bei meiner Meinung, dass ich meine NÃ¤chte nicht irgendwo verbringe und entschied, ihr das auf geeignete Weise mitzuteilen. Zwischen all den Metern Laminat fand ich schlieÃlich einen der wenigen Teppiche, die sie spÃ¤rlich ausgelegt hat. Vermutlich ein vorangegangenes Haustier, auf jeden Fall kein so prÃ¤chtiges Wesen wie ich. An dem Tag sah ich ihr vom Bett aus zu, wie sie den Teppich reinigte."
--
"She calls me Casimir. That supposedly means "troublemaker" in Czech.

I don't know where she gets the idea that this would suit me. I am very neat after all!

Consequently, I regularly let her know what I think of her. The other night, for example, she carried me out of the bedroom while I was sitting next to her head and purring. I tried to take her pillow between my claws, but she stubbornly carried it back to her bed. Insolence.

Stoically, I stuck to my position that I don't spend my nights just anywhere and decided to let her know that in an appropriate way. Between all the yards of laminate, I finally found one of the few rugs she had sparsely laid out. Probably a previous pet, in any case not a magnificent creature like me. With a little vomit, placed in the middle, my message was clearly formulated: If you are going to give me a silly name, then please "Prince Casimir"!

The next day I watched how she cleaned the carpet from the bed."

"As a native of Karl-Marx-Stadt, I returned to the city of Chemnitz during my studies 15 years ago. In the meantime, I was never really far away from the city with the "Nischl", but short distances are quite sexy, especially if you can get to the university by bike - and on the way back you can just let the bike roll...

After my studies, I worked on one or two social projects for educational institutions. Since 2017, I have had my heart's desire. I am the district manager for five Chemnitz districts in the south of the city, which are mainly characterized by Plattenbauten (high-rise buildings). That probably sounds pretty grandiose at first, but above all it's an incredibly varied and great job for the residents, but also for the numerous local institutions, projects, associations and players. From daycare centers to high schools, from citizen police officers to mobile youth work, from small businesses to large landlords - I come into contact with very different fields of work and always learn something new. From illegal garbage dumping to the neighborhood roundtable, where all parties involved meet every two months - I directly and indirectly have responsibility for citizen participation in the neighborhoods and act as a mediator between citizens, community members and the municipality. In doing so, it is also important to generate understanding for each other's concerns.

The past year was also special for me. The highlight of each year is actually the district festival, which I prepare as early as January and February for the most part. Normally, a lot of residents attend the event - from young to old, especially a lot of people with a migration background or disability. It is a great pity to have to cancel many performances, attractions and artists and to see that the preparations of many social institutions have been in vain.
But everything has a new chance; a decaying department store from GDR times in our neighborhoods hosted the city's largest off-culture festival for the first time. More than 4,000 visitors were offered not only works of art by international artists during the celebrations but also a wonderful summer atmosphere that enlivened and moved the district for a few days. I was especially happy about the many contributions of committed citizens who offered guided tours of the district with me or even performed their own songs about their "Heckert area" on stage.

Together with our voluntary editorial team, I produce a district newspaper every three months with a circulation of 6,000 copies. The paper, which is available in many public places, reports on all the big and small news in the area. "Thanks" to Corona, it was also possible this year to take the next step and finally find the time to fulfill the long-held desire for a Facebook and website, so that we can now reach even more people.

Normally I work in a more long-term oriented way. Sometimes, however, things happen very quickly. This was also the case with my personal highlight in 2020: Our districts formed the first part of the secret jury visit for the Capital of Culture application. I found out about it two weeks beforehand and immediately lent a hand. The application was supposed to fit Chemnitz and be down-to-earth. I thought it was a great idea for accompany two citizens with a camera through the canyons of high rises, along the green boulevard to the former airport building and casually introduce the area. When the two got on the streetcar, the cut to the city hall followed. There I had followed the tour and was waiting, ready wired and slightly nervous, together with four fellow participants for my assignment. A half-hour question and answer session with the jury about our districts followed. This was peppered with some not-so-easy questions, but we were able to quickly familiarize ourselves as a team with the situation and also provide the jury with a smile or two. I think we were well remembered by the jury because of some authentic and personal examples like laminated pictures of examples of my work or the "gold washing machine" in a garage.

Six days later I was sitting in the "Kraftverkehr" during the live broadcast of the jury's decision. I will not soon forget the cheers and the surprise when the envelope was opened. The win will shape Chemnitz and our districts in the next few years until 2025 with various projects, such as the newly planted flowering meadows. Our urban area has its own project, "Fritzi51," which revolves around the artistic examination of the history of the Plattenbauten. I am looking forward to it!"

In the meantime, I was never really far away from the city with the "Nischl", but short distances are quite sexy, especially if you can get to the university by bike - and on the way back you can just let the bike roll...

After my studies, I worked on one or two social projects for educational institutions. Since 2017, I have had my heart's desire. I am the district manager for five Chemnitz districts in the south of the city, which are mainly characterized by Plattenbauten (high-rise buildings). That probably sounds pretty grandiose at first, but above all it's an incredibly varied and great job for the residents, but also for the numerous local institutions, projects, associations and players. From daycare centers to high schools, from citizen police officers to mobile youth work, from small businesses to large landlords - I come into contact with very different fields of work and always learn something new. From illegal garbage dumping to the neighborhood roundtable, where all parties involved meet every two months - I directly and indirectly have responsibility for citizen participation in the neighborhoods and act as a mediator between citizens, community members and the municipality. In doing so, it is also important to generate understanding for each other's concerns.

The past year was also special for me. The highlight of each year is actually the district festival, which I prepare as early as January and February for the most part. Normally, a lot of residents attend the event - from young to old, especially a lot of people with a migration background or disability. It is a great pity to have to cancel many performances, attractions and artists and to see that the preparations of many social institutions have been in vain.
But everything has a new chance; a decaying department store from GDR times in our neighborhoods hosted the city's largest off-culture festival for the first time. More than 4,000 visitors were offered not only works of art by international artists during the celebrations but also a wonderful summer atmosphere that enlivened and moved the district for a few days. I was especially happy about the many contributions of committed citizens who offered guided tours of the district with me or even performed their own songs about their "Heckert area" on stage.

Together with our voluntary editorial team, I produce a district newspaper every three months with a circulation of 6,000 copies. The paper, which is available in many public places, reports on all the big and small news in the area. "Thanks" to Corona, it was also possible this year to take the next step and finally find the time to fulfill the long-held desire for a Facebook and website, so that we can now reach even more people.

Normally I work in a more long-term oriented way. Sometimes, however, things happen very quickly. This was also the case with my personal highlight in 2020: Our districts formed the first part of the secret jury visit for the Capital of Culture application. I found out about it two weeks beforehand and immediately lent a hand. The application was supposed to fit Chemnitz and be down-to-earth. I thought it was a great idea for accompany two citizens with a camera through the canyons of high rises, along the green boulevard to the former airport building and casually introduce the area. When the two got on the streetcar, the cut to the city hall followed. There I had followed the tour and was waiting, ready wired and slightly nervous, together with four fellow participants for my assignment. A half-hour question and answer session with the jury about our districts followed. This was peppered with some not-so-easy questions, but we were able to quickly familiarize ourselves as a team with the situation and also provide the jury with a smile or two. I think we were well remembered by the jury because of some authentic and personal examples like laminated pictures of examples of my work or the "gold washing machine" in a garage.

Six days later I was sitting in the "Kraftverkehr" during the live broadcast of the jury's decision. I will not soon forget the cheers and the surprise when the envelope was opened. The win will shape Chemnitz and our districts in the next few years until 2025 with various projects, such as the newly planted flowering meadows. Our urban area has its own project, "Fritzi51," which revolves around the artistic examination of the history of the Plattenbauten. I am looking forward to it!"

"I have been living in Chemnitz now since March 2015. Personally, I have not had any problems, but I have seen many things that I do not like. I was afraid during the demonstrations last summer. There are good people and bad people everywhere, and I have had no trouble with bad people.

I came from Syria via Turkey and was then in Munich in a home and the BAMF said after two days that I should go to Chemnitz.They gave us a train ticket and said we were going to Chemnitz. I didn't know the city, I had only heard the name "Chemnitz."

I immediately started to learn German and while I was taking German, I attended barber school. In Syria, I was a barber and here I wanted to work in my profession again. I did a small internship and received a lot of support from the employees of the hairdressers' guild. I am very grateful to them. After that I started at Klier, later I was at Dietze Coiffeur and then I was at Maximilian Barbershop on the Street of Nations for three years. In 2020, I established and opened my own place and during this time I attended the master school. I have now passed most of the exams and I am only missing the practical part. Because of Corona that was postponed and let's see when I can take the exam.

I would like to be allowed to work again, and I hope that the Corona situation improves, that is important to me, and my biggest wish is that there is no more war in my home country and that my parents stay healthy. My parents are there and I am alone here, I am not married yet, although I would like to get married. I always say: parents and brothers and sisters are the only things you can't buy in the supermarket. I miss them a lot. I haven't seen them for five years. I am not allowed to enter the country nor can I.

Right now I'm practicing a bit for the master school: perm, updo, color and so on, and just technique. The exam was supposed to be in March, online classes start next week, and we'll have to see how it goes. I think it doesn't matter where you are. If you really want to get something done, you can get it done! And it was also important to me that I do something. I didn't want to live off the state. I have to support myself ,and I have to work. Chemnitz, that is work for me."

We are interrupting our series from Chemnitz for this interview, which is also very close to our hearts.

"I am the founder and owner of the gallery and art shop ART-ICALS in the Neustadt. We specialize in small artists and hobby artists and offer a sales and marketing platform.

After graduating from high school, I became an educator and worked for a while in a children's home in Erfurt. But that was not for me - looking back I was probably too young for that job. After that I traveled through Asia for a year and decided to study political science, which I did until I got my master's degree. After graduating, it wasn't going to work out directly with a job. So I fulfilled my childhood dream of owning my own business. I came to art rather like the virgin to the child. Of course - art has always played a role in my life. As an educator, I had worked in a creative center during my training. As a political scientist, I was interested in cultural and political topics. Painting pictures, however, was more of a hobby, and I neglected it.

In 2019, the project ART-ICALS was created. Hobby and small artists have it very hard, especially in Dresden. Often, art and artworks are about names: Who studied where with whom? The quality of the works or the art plays a secondary role, it seems to me. Autodidacts have not infrequently created incredible works and don't need to worry about comparison with established artists. Such works can be found in our gallery. We focus on the art and not on the prominence of the painter. I and my team are all artists ourselves, we are united by the love of art. The separation between art creators and art commercialization is somewhat removed here. The gallery was founded by artists and has been run by artists ever since. What is important to me personally is that people think about whether they want to buy pictures and posters in the hardware store, some of which are produced in a less than sustainable manner and transported around the world - or whether they want to support local artists. So that one asks the question about the difference between industrial mass-market products and individual unique pieces. Sustainable consumption doesn't stop with food.

We differentiate ourselves through ordinariness and everydayness. In some galleries, you quickly get the impression of being in a sterile hospital. The exclusionary habitus and the upscale promise of luxury strike me as alienating and uninviting. We strive for proximity and connections - creativity only works together. For example, behind our exhibition space is a workshop - visitors can experience the creation of the art and, in some cases, the artists themselves. You could say we are a modern producer's gallery. And we organize authentic exhibitions - without pretense but with heart and soul. Our exhibition space reflects a cross-section of our artists' works - many different styles, techniques and approaches are on display here, right next to each other. The space has an inspiring and stimulating effect, not only on me and other artists, but also on clients and interested visitors. Our philosophy is to encourage creativity - this happens in all directions and areas.
At this point, I can hardly imagine my life without the gallery and without painting pictures. I burn for the cause, get involved with our artists, organize creative and cultural events and get absorbed in the gallery life.

The response to our concept has been overwhelmingly positive so far - even though we have hardly any reach and have gained little notoriety. We are still an inside tip, you could say. This year, if it is possible with the Corona, we intend to grow and establish ourselves on the art market. Of course, we are very much affected by the corona pandemic - but so is most of the cultural sector. Since the complete lockdown, I've been putting my energy and a lot of effort into building and expanding the web store. We carry not only paintings, but other creative works like jewelry and home decor. Some things are quite innovative, you can't find them anywhere else. However, since Christmas, sales have been poor. Still, I'm optimistic about the future.

For this year, I hope that the public and cultural life of the city will be revived. That a bit of normality returns and people enjoy music and art events together again. I hope that love will prevail over fear. That is perhaps a bit too much pathos. But in 2020, many fears and doubts were stoked, leading to isolation, distance and separation. Hopefully, this year this trend will be reversed and people will once again reach out to each other."

We are interrupting our series from Chemnitz for this interview, which is also very close to our hearts.

"I am the founder and owner of the gallery and art shop ART-ICALS in the Neustadt. We specialize in small artists and hobby artists and offer a sales and marketing platform.

After graduating from high school, I became an educator and worked for a while in a children's home in Erfurt. But that was not for me - looking back I was probably too young for that job. After that I traveled through Asia for a year and decided to study political science, which I did until I got my master's degree. After graduating, it wasn't going to work out directly with a job. So I fulfilled my childhood dream of owning my own business. I came to art rather like the virgin to the child. Of course - art has always played a role in my life. As an educator, I had worked in a creative center during my training. As a political scientist, I was interested in cultural and political topics. Painting pictures, however, was more of a hobby, and I neglected it.

In 2019, the project ART-ICALS was created. Hobby and small artists have it very hard, especially in Dresden. Often, art and artworks are about names: Who studied where with whom? The quality of the works or the art plays a secondary role, it seems to me. Autodidacts have not infrequently created incredible works and don't need to worry about comparison with established artists. Such works can be found in our gallery. We focus on the art and not on the prominence of the painter. I and my team are all artists ourselves, we are united by the love of art. The separation between art creators and art commercialization is somewhat removed here. The gallery was founded by artists and has been run by artists ever since. What is important to me personally is that people think about whether they want to buy pictures and posters in the hardware store, some of which are produced in a less than sustainable manner and transported around the world - or whether they want to support local artists. So that one asks the question about the difference between industrial mass-market products and individual unique pieces. Sustainable consumption doesn't stop with food.

We differentiate ourselves through ordinariness and everydayness. In some galleries, you quickly get the impression of being in a sterile hospital. The exclusionary habitus and the upscale promise of luxury strike me as alienating and uninviting. We strive for proximity and connections - creativity only works together. For example, behind our exhibition space is a workshop - visitors can experience the creation of the art and, in some cases, the artists themselves. You could say we are a modern producer's gallery. And we organize authentic exhibitions - without pretense but with heart and soul. Our exhibition space reflects a cross-section of our artists' works - many different styles, techniques and approaches are on display here, right next to each other. The space has an inspiring and stimulating effect, not only on me and other artists, but also on clients and interested visitors. Our philosophy is to encourage creativity - this happens in all directions and areas.
At this point, I can hardly imagine my life without the gallery and without painting pictures. I burn for the cause, get involved with our artists, organize creative and cultural events and get absorbed in the gallery life.

The response to our concept has been overwhelmingly positive so far - even though we have hardly any reach and have gained little notoriety. We are still an inside tip, you could say. This year, if it is possible with the Corona, we intend to grow and establish ourselves on the art market. Of course, we are very much affected by the corona pandemic - but so is most of the cultural sector. Since the complete lockdown, I've been putting my energy and a lot of effort into building and expanding the web store. We carry not only paintings, but other creative works like jewelry and home decor. Some things are quite innovative, you can't find them anywhere else. However, since Christmas, sales have been poor. Still, I'm optimistic about the future.

For this year, I hope that the public and cultural life of the city will be revived. That a bit of normality returns and people enjoy music and art events together again. I hope that love will prevail over fear. That is perhaps a bit too much pathos. But in 2020, many fears and doubts were stoked, leading to isolation, distance and separation. Hopefully, this year this trend will be reversed and people will once again reach out to each other."

"I was born in Karl Marx-Stadt and grew up in Heckert. I always thought it was cool here and I never want to leave my beautiful Chemnitz. I also lived in Dresden, but it' too big for me. Here it's nice and small and cozy and even if many say Chemnitz is old-fashioned, I love my Chemnitz.

I think it's very cool that Chemnitz will be the Capital of Culture 2025 and I didn't think it would happen like this because there were a few other cool cities in the running! But I think it's great for Chemnitz and for the development of the city. You have also seen in recent years how the cityscape has changed for the better: It has become much more modern. Of course, it can't compete with big cities, but I think it's very nice.

For example, I really like the fact that everything is being redone on BrÃ¼hl. You can take a nice walk there now. The city center has also become beautiful, compared to the condition five years ago, there are now much fewer construction sites, the SMAC is great, the city center and the BrÃ¼hl are really worth seeing!

I don't know the Heckert area today, I only know it from before because I was a "Heckert kid", and when people hear that today, they always think it wasn't nice at all. But I thought it was good back then. You could go out, you had buddies everywhere, it was all familiar. But now I'm never there. People still associate it with the apartment blocks. That's all I can say about it. I don't have anything to do with the area anymore.

I'm a police officer by profession, and from my professional perspective, I would say that the inner city is also a magnet for crime. But that doesn't mean that Chemnitz is a highly criminal city, it's the case everywhere that the inner cities are the busiest, and that includes crime, that's no surprise.
As a woman in the police profession, you have to be self-confident. Smaller women certainly have a harder time gaining respect than larger, solid women. I think you have to earn respect more from the general public. You have to be more hardened than a man to stand your ground and assert yourself. When you're on the street, you have to listen to a lot of things as both a man and a woman. It depends on the counterpart more than anything else. The opinion that things are getting worse on the streets and that respect for policemen and policewomen is generally being lost is something I would only partly endorse. Here, too, it depends on who is standing opposite you. And of course on the condition of the person, for example, is the person intoxicated or sober, young or old? That also makes a difference.

Since I became a mother, I have had an office job and am no longer on the street. My heart used to long for patrol, but with the family in the background, I now investigate from my desk, which is also exciting. The exciting thing about patrol was that you never knew what was going to happen today, you get called somewhere and you never really know what to expect. And you're always dealing with very different personalities. That can also stress you out, and you have to learn to put it aside when you go home. That's also a reason why - especially as a woman, but also as a man - you have to be mentally strong. You have to be able to live with some situations. It's your job, you have to do it and then you have to find a way for yourself to deal with it. As a mom of two kids, it's a little bit harder because you always want to come back home healthy and happy and I really mean that. There were often situations where I thought to myself: "No, I'm a mom, I have to arrive home healthy again." Not so many dangerous situations arise at the office.

I exercise a lot at home because I need the exercise to clear my head from all the sitting in front of the computer. But of course, exercise never hurts. You also wear the bulletproof vest, which weighs a bit, you might have to run after someone, so yes, fitness is important in my opinion.

Actually, becoming a police officer was never on my agenda. I originally wanted to study mechanical engineering or engineering because I have a technical high school diploma. Funnily enough, the police did come into play. My grandfather was in the police, then I applied and it worked out right away and I'm glad I did it and I don't regret it yet because it's really a very versatile job and you always have to deal with people and that's exactly what I like.
With Corona, social contacts have become more limited, on the one hand for children and on the other hand for family and friends, but I feel that the positive thing is that you find your way back to yourself and your own family and simply use the time more as a foursome. But it's hard when you're not allowed to see your friends anymore. I hope we are all spared from Corona.

For Chemnitz, I would hope that everyone who's not from here might like to come here, especially if there's a little more going on here, and then say, "Chemnitz isn't so bad!" It's always the case that many people think: "Oh, you're Saxon, you're from Chemnitz...", that's always so negatively charged and I wish that this would improve and that people wouldn't always assume that Saxony and Chemnitz aren't attractive but instead see that there are also beautiful things to discover here!"

The city center has also become beautiful, compared to the condition five years ago, there are now much fewer construction sites, the SMAC is great, the city center and the BrÃ¼hl are really worth seeing!

I don't know the Heckert area today, I only know it from before because I was a "Heckert kid", and when people hear that today, they always think it wasn't nice at all. But I thought it was good back then. You could go out, you had buddies everywhere, it was all familiar. But now I'm never there. People still associate it with the apartment blocks. That's all I can say about it. I don't have anything to do with the area anymore.

I'm a police officer by profession, and from my professional perspective, I would say that the inner city is also a magnet for crime. But that doesn't mean that Chemnitz is a highly criminal city, it's the case everywhere that the inner cities are the busiest, and that includes crime, that's no surprise.
As a woman in the police profession, you have to be self-confident. Smaller women certainly have a harder time gaining respect than larger, solid women. I think you have to earn respect more from the general public. You have to be more hardened than a man to stand your ground and assert yourself. When you're on the street, you have to listen to a lot of things as both a man and a woman. It depends on the counterpart more than anything else. The opinion that things are getting worse on the streets and that respect for policemen and policewomen is generally being lost is something I would only partly endorse. Here, too, it depends on who is standing opposite you. And of course on the condition of the person, for example, is the person intoxicated or sober, young or old? That also makes a difference.

Since I became a mother, I have had an office job and am no longer on the street. My heart used to long for patrol, but with the family in the background, I now investigate from my desk, which is also exciting. The exciting thing about patrol was that you never knew what was going to happen today, you get called somewhere and you never really know what to expect. And you're always dealing with very different personalities. That can also stress you out, and you have to learn to put it aside when you go home. That's also a reason why - especially as a woman, but also as a man - you have to be mentally strong. You have to be able to live with some situations. It's your job, you have to do it and then you have to find a way for yourself to deal with it. As a mom of two kids, it's a little bit harder because you always want to come back home healthy and happy and I really mean that. There were often situations where I thought to myself: "No, I'm a mom, I have to arrive home healthy again." Not so many dangerous situations arise at the office.

I exercise a lot at home because I need the exercise to clear my head from all the sitting in front of the computer. But of course, exercise never hurts. You also wear the bulletproof vest, which weighs a bit, you might have to run after someone, so yes, fitness is important in my opinion.

Actually, becoming a police officer was never on my agenda. I originally wanted to study mechanical engineering or engineering because I have a technical high school diploma. Funnily enough, the police did come into play. My grandfather was in the police, then I applied and it worked out right away and I'm glad I did it and I don't regret it yet because it's really a very versatile job and you always have to deal with people and that's exactly what I like.
With Corona, social contacts have become more limited, on the one hand for children and on the other hand for family and friends, but I feel that the positive thing is that you find your way back to yourself and your own family and simply use the time more as a foursome. But it's hard when you're not allowed to see your friends anymore. I hope we are all spared from Corona.

For Chemnitz, I would hope that everyone who's not from here might like to come here, especially if there's a little more going on here, and then say, "Chemnitz isn't so bad!" It's always the case that many people think: "Oh, you're Saxon, you're from Chemnitz...", that's always so negatively charged and I wish that this would improve and that people wouldn't always assume that Saxony and Chemnitz aren't attractive but instead see that there are also beautiful things to discover here!"

Man sagt ja auch, dass groÃe Erwartungen enttÃ¤uscht werden kÃ¶nnen, aber in Tokyo wurden meine Erwartungen Ã¼bertroffen. Die Menschen dort sind Ã¼beraus freundlich und sehr hilfsbereit. Ich hatte da ein viel hÃ¶heres SicherheitsgefÃ¼hl. In dieser Stadt mit 30 Mio. Einwohnern habe ich mich selbst nachts nie unsicher gefÃ¼hlt. Wir haben in einem Haus fÃ¼r 20 bis 30 internationale GÃ¤ste gelebt und an diesem Haus gab es eine TÃ¼r aus Pergamentpapier. An meinem Ankunftstag habe ich versucht, mit einem SchlÃ¼ssel, den man mir gegeben hatte, das Tor vor dem Haus zu Ã¶ffnen. Ich war schon 30-40 Stunden auf den Beinen und ganz schÃ¶n fertig und habe das Tor einfach nicht Ã¶ffnen kÃ¶nnen. Da kam ein Mann aus dem Haus und hat gelacht und mich gefragt, ob ich hier neu bin. Hier sei nichts abgeschlossen und man kÃ¶nne das Tor einfach Ã¶ffnen!

Ich denke, die Menschen da konzentrieren sich mehr auf die Gesellschaft als auf den Einzelnen. Durch den Aufenthalt in Tokyo habe ich gemerkt, wie fokussiert wir EuropÃ¤er auf uns selbst sind. Ein Beispiel dafÃ¼r sind gerade die Masken. Die Japaner, die eine Maske tragen, denken: Ich will die anderen nicht anstecken. Das ist zwar jetzt ein bisschen Ã¼bergeneralisiert, aber insgesamt ist das Maske-Tragen dort selbstverstÃ¤ndlicher, um andere zu schÃ¼tzen. Vielleicht kÃ¶nnten wir uns davon etwas abschneiden.
Wohin es als nÃ¤chstes geht, kann ich noch nicht sagen. Jetzt mÃ¼ssen wir erstmal gemeinsam durchhalten.â
--
"I am currently a research assistant at the TU Chemnitz. I got the position in the traditional way by applying for a job posting. Previously, I was at the TU Dresden in the project "German for Refugees," and I have discovered many of my students from this time on People in Dresden.

I myself also studied German language and literature in Chemnitz. In fact, I made a conscious decision to study in Chemnitz because I liked the support here, which was unlike a giant university like Dresden or Berlin. Chemnitz has always been a point of reference for me, since I am originally from Freiberg. After I had applied to several universities, I felt like the university in Chemnitz was the most interested in its students, because I immediately received friendly feedback by mail and this impression was confirmed in reality. In addition, you can major in comprehensive German studies in Chemnitz, i.e. German as a foreign and second language is integrated into the German studies program, which was not common at the time.

I also enjoy working at the university now. Under corona conditions, of course, it is more difficult, but for the good of everyone - students as well as lecturers - we do our best in teaching at a distance. In the beginning, things didn't run smoothly with the equipment, but we've since settled in.

After my studies, I did an internship in Tokyo, then one in Nancy, and then I was in the Netherlands before teaching at a DaZ elementary school and finally at the TU Dresden. My absolute favorite place is Japan. I don't know why I always wanted to go there either. They say that high expectations can be disappointed, but in Tokyo my expectations were exceeded. The people there are extremely friendly and very helpful. I had a much higher feeling of security. In this city of 30 million people, I never felt unsafe even at night. We lived in a house for 20 to 30 international guests, and the house had a door made of parchment paper. On the day I arrived, I tried to open the gate in front of the house with a key they had given me. I had been on my feet for 30-40 hours and was pretty beat up and just couldn't open the gate. Then a man came out of the house and laughed and asked me if I was new here. He said nothing is locked here and you can just open the gate!

I think people there focus more on society than on the individual. Staying in Tokyo made me realize how focused we Europeans are on ourselves. An example of that is the masks. The Japanese, who wear a mask, think: I don't want to infect the others. That's a bit overgeneralized, but overall, mask-wearing is more natural there in order to protect others. Maybe we could take a leaf out of that book.

I can't say yet where things will go next. For now, we have to hang in there together."

"Ich hatte eine echt beschissene Vergangenheit hinter mir. Ich hatte jede MÃ¶glichkeit, die Sprache zu verkacken, die Schule genauso und mein Arbeitsleben noch dazu. In Deutschland das eigene Leben zu verkacken, kann so schnell gehen. Man hat alle MÃ¶glichkeiten, was man aus sich macht. Dieses Land ermÃ¶glicht jedem den Zugang zu jeder Art von den Drogen und gleichzeitig zu jeder Art von Erfolg.

Der erste Erfolg war die Sprache. Ich habe mich seit Tag eins fÃ¼r die Sprache interessiert. Ich wollte einfach endlich alles alleine erledigen kÃ¶nnen, die Frau ansprechen, die ich hÃ¼bsch finde, dahin zu gehen, wo ich will, ohne Hilfe von irgendjemandem zu brauchen, das zu erreichen, was mir SpaÃ macht. Dann folgte die Schule. Obwohl ich aus drei Schulen rausgeschmissen wurde, da ich einfach der Meinung war, dass ein Abschluss nicht mein Leben bestimmt, und ich fast jeden Tag die Schule geschwÃ¤nzt habe. Am Ende hatte ich alles einfach satt. Ich wollte einfach irgendeinen Abschluss machen und habe den Realschulabschluss mit einem Durchschnitt von 2,3 gemacht. Man muss kein Genie sein, um einen Abschluss zu haben, man muss die Sprache nicht perfekt sprechen, man braucht nur den Willen.

Vor Ã¼ber zweieinhalb Jahren habe ich mit MMA angefangen. Ich wusste damals Ã¼berhaupt nicht, was der Kampfsport mit einer Person machen kann. Wenn ich jetzt aber zurÃ¼ckblicke, sehe ich, dass der Kampfsport mich zu dem gemacht hat, der ich jetzt bin. Kampfsport als Hobby zu haben, kann das Leben einer Person um 180 Grad ins Positive Ã¤ndern. Man macht dadurch tÃ¤glich Sport, tÃ¤glich geht man an seine Grenzen, tÃ¤glich geht man nach Hause mit dem Gedanken: Heute bin ich besser geworden. Leider haben viele Menschen Angst davor, sowas auszuprobieren und trauen sich nicht, doch wenn sie es einmal probiert haben, werden sie sehen, dass so ein Sport ein respektvoller Sport ist, bei dem man in jeder Trainingseinheit Vollgas gibt, um voranzukommen. Wenn man das tagtÃ¤glich erlebt, zieht das automatisch in das private Leben ein und man fÃ¤ngt an, nicht nur sportlich besser zu werden sondern auch im Leben! 

Fast das volle Selbstbewusstsein, das ich jetzt habe, entstand durch den Kampfsport. Ich hatte jeden Tag, zweieinhalb Jahre lang tÃ¤glich mindestens eine Trainingseinheit. Ich habe jede dieser Personen ausgelacht und die Idee trotzdem umgesetzt. Mit den beiden Berufen verdiene ich einen Haufen Geld, viel zu viel Ã¼ber dem Durchschnitt. Sowas als Syrer zu erleben ist selten, doch man muss nur an sich glauben und man schafft alles."

" had a really shitty past behind me. I had every opportunity to mess up the language, school as well, and my working life to boot. Screwing up your life in Germany can happen so quickly. You have all the opportunities to choose what you make of yourself. This country gives everyone access to every kind of the drugs and at the same time to every kind of success.
The first success was the language. I was interested in the language since day one. I just wanted to finally be able to do everything on my own, to approach the woman I think is pretty, to go where I want without needing help from anyone, to achieve what is fun for me. Then came school. I got kicked out of three schools because I just felt that a degree didn't define my life, and I skipped school almost every day. In the end, I just got tired of everything. I just wanted to get some kind of degree, and I graduated from Realschule with a 2.3 average. You don't have to be a genius to have a degree, you don't have to speak the language perfectly, you just need the will.
I started doing MMA over two and a half years ago. At that time, I didn't know at all what the martial arts could do to a person. But now when I look back, I see that martial arts made me who I am now. Having martial arts as a hobby can change a person's life 180 degrees to the positive. It makes you exercise every day, it makes you push yourself to your limits every day, and it makes you go home thinking, "Today I got better." Unfortunately, a lot of people are afraid to try something like this, but once they try it, they will see that it is a respectful sport, where you push yourself hard in every training session to progress. When you experience that on a daily basis, it automatically moves into your personal life, and you start to get better not only athletically but in life as well!

Almost all of the self-confidence I have now came from martial arts. I had at least one training session every day for two and a half years. I admit that without martial arts I would have stopped at various points, but only the people who do a lot of sports know that after each training session you feel so good that afterwards you can tackle all the problems in peace, because your brain is capable of it again at that moment. Look for a sport that moves you forward. If it gives you pleasure and makes you physically fitter, then it's no longer a sport, it's a hobby.

Since I was 17, I've been thinking about self-employment. In the beginning it was just an idea. More than half of the people looked at me with a smile - as if no Syrian had ever managed to start his own business at the age of 18. I laughed at each of these people and implemented the idea anyway. I started my own business in finance and real estate sales in early 2020 and later started as a freelance interpreter. With the two professions, I make a bunch of money, way too much above average. To experience something like this as a Syrian is rare, but you just have to believe in yourself, and you can do anything."
(Part 2 of 2)
