"Ich komme aus Syrien, Damaskus. Ich habe vierzehn Jahre in den Vereinigten Arabischen Emiraten gelebt. Im Oktober 2015 habe ich mich mit meinem Bruder als FlÃ¼chtlinge auf den Weg nach Deutschland gemacht, da wir sehr groÃe finanzielle Probleme hatten. Wir waren kurz davor, nach Syrien abgeschoben zu werden, als die Lage in Syrien noch am schlechtesten war. Ich bin hierher auf dem klassischen Weg gekommen - von der TÃ¼rkei mit dem Boot bis Griechenland und ab da bis nach Deutschland. Ich kam mit meinem Bruder in Straubing, MÃ¼nchen an. Wir wollten nach Hamburg, aber wurden im Zug von der Polizei erwischt und nach Dresden geschickt. Mein Bruder ist 2017 nach Hannover umgezogen. Ich lebe weiter in Dresden, da ich hier von Anfang an meine Wohngemeinschaft vom Jugendamt und meine Schule hatte. 

Ehrlicherweise wÃ¤re ich am liebsten schon lÃ¤ngst umgezogen. Ich wollte von Anfang an in eine Stadt umziehen, in der es schon viele AuslÃ¤nder gibt. Zu dem Zeitpunkt war Dresden schon voller AuslÃ¤nder, aber die Deutschen waren ganz am Anfang an sowas nicht gewÃ¶hnt. Das war der Grund, warum ich umziehen wollte, doch mit der Zeit hat sich Dresden in dieser Beziehung stark ins Positive geÃ¤ndert. Langsam wurde Dresden zu einer Stadt, in der man Integration beider Seiten gesehen hat. Zum einen die Integration der AuslÃ¤nder, dass sie kapieren, dass sie jetzt in einem anderen Land sind. Zum anderen die Integration der Deutschen, dass sie auch kapieren, dass AuslÃ¤nder genauso Menschen sind.

Jede Beziehung, die ich zu irgendeinem Deutschen aufgebaut habe, hat mein Deutsch verbessert, auch wenn ich nur ein neues Wort gelernt habe, Hauptsache ich habe was neues dazu gelernt. Die gesamte Sprache und die Grammatik, die ich beherrsche, kam durch den Kontakt zu den Deutschen (bzw. zu Menschen, die gut Deutsch kÃ¶nnen), Sprache durch die StraÃe und Grammatik durch die Schule. Das ist auch das erste, was ich jedem empfehlen wÃ¼rde, um schnell Deutsch sprechen zu kÃ¶nnen, nÃ¤mlich direkt Kontakt zu Deutschen aufbauen, egal wie, Hauptsache man hat die MÃ¶glichkeit diese Sprache zu sprechen bzw. zu hÃ¶ren, um zu lernen, anders geht es nicht. Die Schule alleine kann einem niemals die Sprache beibringen, ich kenne viele Menschen, die jede Art von Kursen gemacht haben und immer noch nur Grammatik und paar Sachen kennen, doch wenn es um die Sprache geht, kÃ¶nnen sie sehr wenig, da sie die Sprache nicht nutzen. 

Ganz am Anfang wurde man als AuslÃ¤nder schon komisch angeguckt. Mit der Zeit verschwand das allerdings und die Menschen in Dresden haben sich mit der Zeit an sowas gewÃ¶hnt. Irgendwann wurde es zu etwas normalem. Jetzt erlebt man es kaum, dass man komisch angeguckt wird beziehungsweise dass einem etwas gesagt wird wie: âGeh in dein Land zurÃ¼ck!â oder so ein Ã¤hnlicher ScheiÃ. NatÃ¼rlich gibt es sowas ab und zu, allerdings wirklich sehr wenig im Vergleich zu damals. Auch die jungen Deutschen haben schon seit mehr als drei Jahren damit angefangen, intensiv Kontakt zu AuslÃ¤ndern aufzubauen. Man trifft sehr viele Deutsche,deren Freundschaften zu Ã¼ber fÃ¼nfzig Prozent zu AuslÃ¤ndern sind. Hier sieht man, dass die Deutschen am Anfang ganz andere Vorstellungen von AuslÃ¤ndern hatten, bis sie Kontakt mit den AuslÃ¤ndern bekamen. 2016 wollten die jÃ¼ngeren Deutschen fast Ã¼berhaupt keinen Kontakt zu AuslÃ¤ndern haben; ich habe das selbst erlebt. Jetzt vergeht kein Tag, an dem ich nicht mindestens zwÃ¶lf Stunden Kontakt zu Deutschen habe. Die Deutschen sprechen mittlerweile fast besser Arabisch als wir."

Teil 1/2
--
"I am from Syria, Damascus, I lived in the United Arab Emirates for fourteen years. In October 2015, I made my way to Germany with my brother as refugees, because we had very big financial problems. We were about to be deported to Syria when the situation in Syria was at its worst. I came here the usual way - from Turkey by boat to Greece and from there to Germany. I arrived with my brother in Straubing, Munich. We wanted to go to Hamburg but were caught by the police on the train and sent to Dresden. My brother moved to Hanover in 2017. I continue to live in Dresden, because from the beginning I had my shared apartment from the Youth Welfare Office and my school here.

Honestly, I would have preferred to move a long time ago. From the beginning, I wanted to move to a city where there were already lots of foreigners. At that time, Dresden was already full of foreigners, but the Germans were not used to it at the very beginning. That was the reason why I wanted to move, but with time Dresden has changed a lot in a positive way. Slowly Dresden became a city where you saw integration on both sides. On the one hand, the integration of the foreigners, that they understand that they are now in another country. On the other hand, the integration of the Germans, that they also understand that foreigners are human beings.

Every relationship I have built up with a German has improved my German, even if I have only learned one new word, the main thing is that I have learned something new. "I have been in Chemnitz since 2011, when I started studying German language and literature here at the Technical University. Ten years later, I'm still here, and that despite the fact that I've already told friends and acquaintances that I would leave the city at the next best opportunity. During my studies I spent several months in the Czech Republic (where I am originally from), giving tours of the KarlÅ¡tejn Castle near Prague, and later I worked in Killybegs, Ireland for a few weeks volunteering at a bed and breakfast. In 2017, I spent a semester abroad with the Erasmus+ program in Turku, Finland, where among other things I met my current life partner. (Long distance relationships in Corona times, yay...) Pretty soon I felt that the world was open for me, and so it was after my studies I decided that I would definitely leave not only Chemnitz, but also Germany. When I handed in my master thesis, it was finally time to go. With my degree in my pocket, I went to Scotland to work as a tour guide for German tourists. And quite honestly, there couldn't have been a nicer working environment. My office was the Highlands, the deep lochs and glens, and my "sales product" were my stories. It not only gave me endless fun to give people an unforgettable time with my information about one of the most beautiful countries in the world, coupled with traveling through the breathtaking scenery, an unforgettable time, but it also made me happy. As happy as I have ever been in my life. And yet after a few months I noticed that something was missing, that I had not yet "fully" left Chemnitz. Do you understand what I mean?

When I reflected on my time in Chemnitz, I realized that I had not only studied here but also built a life for myself. I play here with wonderful musicians in the band "Story of A Dead Man", dance in the local Scottish Country Dance Club, and have some of my best friends in this city. I felt it wasn't time to leave all this yet. In addition, I realized that my studies were not be over yet either. As a literary scholar, I wanted to go one step further and get my Ph.D and so I applied for a position as a research assistant at the TU Chemnitz for the Chair of Modern German and Comparative Literature. Successfully, and lo and behold, since 2019 I am back in Chemnitz. 

And what do you think has happened since then? Again, I tell my friends and acquaintances that I will leave the city after my PhD and so at the next best opportunity. And do you know what? I don't think it's a bad thing at all. I know that I will never be 100 percent happy in Chemnitz, but I also know that it's not the right time to leave yet. I still don't feel "finished," and I feel that Chemnitz is the perfect place to walk through that completion. 

The city here offers me so many opportunities to define myself, to try myself out, to get to know myself and most of all, it gives me the space I need to become the person I would like to be. The international diversity of the city allows me to get to know people from all over the world and their customs, and the cultural scene allows me to get involved in a wide range of different activities of the most diverse kind.

Chemnitz is colorful, wild, vibrant, and yet I notice a certain calmness that gives me the chance to concentrate on myself. And before I go out into the world again I know that this is the most important thing at the moment. Because of the whole Corona pandemic and all the time I've spent in isolation, it's made me think about a lot of things -- too much, if you ask me. I have realized that I need to "clean up my life, that I have not yet processed past things, and that I need to spend much invest more time in my own well-being. And I know that Chemnitz is the place where I can and want to do this. On my long and seemingly endless train ride, Chemnitz is definitely not my final stop. However, until I know where I will ultimately be drawn, the city will remain my familiar stopover. Chemnitz is certainly not an empty and dreary platform with a mere arrival and departure timetable, but a cozy station with a multitude of colorful shops and enough colorful stores and plenty of opportunities to relax. And I know that I am in good hands here until I jump on my next train. Where to? I can't say at the moment or whether there is a destination station at all. But honestly, does there have to be?"

""I was born in Berlin, grew up in Thuringia and came to Chemnitz because of my studies. I have worked here because I found it so beautiful, and love keeps me here too, I got married last year. Right now we are building a little house in Chemnitz.

I work at the University of Chemnitz as a project manager at the Accelerator (TUClab). I support new companies in establishing themselves on the market here. Each year, we accept three applicants into our class who impress us and who are then mentored for a year. The selection is done in a competitive process and every year more start-ups apply. In addition to coaching and networking meetings, we provide access to the infrastructure of the TU Chemnitz and its network partners, and finally the companies receive a financial boost from the SÃ¤chsische Beteiligungsgesellschaft SBG. All start-ups also focus on the areas of expertise of the TU Chemnitz: the human-technology interface, innovative lightweight products or new manufacturing processes. These are the core competencies of the TU and these are also found in the start-ups, such as a company for high-strength synthetic fiber ropes or people who have developed an innovative abrasive water jet cutting process. Others are working on sensor technology for blast furnaces or rapid prototyping for microchips, we have virtual and augmented reality bundled into one start-up - the whole spectrum is there!

We have the luxury of being able to respond relatively individually to our teams. The classic start-up approach is that, in addition to coaching, you also offer an investment, but that's not up to us, it's up to SBG, and so I can then say, okay, we'll start financed, of course, what do you want? We then have a 12-step program with which we approach the founder teams. If, for example, they need more coaching in the area of tax advice or want support with CE certification, then we can either handle it ourselves or have our network partners or external coaches provide the founders with the best possible support. So I don't have to hover omnipotently over everyone, but the founder teams can become proactive; they also constantly exchange ideas.

In Chemnitz, there are of course problems with the rightwing mob, Chemnitz is a city of migration, it is the oldest city in Europe, it is a former fallow industrial city - these are always the arguments "against". But some of them can also harbor beauty. Not the mob, of course, but the industrial city for sure! I just read today that Chemnitz has the cheapest rents among cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants. That also says a bit about the character of the city. For me, this is the reserved Chemnitz Saxon, which also reflects the way of being and which of course makes you want to settle here. Of course, we don't have the great cultural program of Dresden or Leipzig or the lake landscape. But you don't need them. You are so close to these cities and if you are interested in going to Saxon Switzerland, for example, you can do that. As a someone building a home, I'd much rather take the opportunity to get a house here for an affordable price. When I see my poor Leipzig friends looking at the real estate market, wanting to afford a home of their own and then realizing, aha, with the income we have, we have to set the limit at 90 sq meters...

I'm excited to see what the 2025 Capital of Culture will bring to Chemnitz. I've already dared to participate in the preparations: I approached the Capital of Culture committee because I want like to swim down the Danube in 2022 and thought it would be cool to take a message of greeting to every city that lies along the course of the river. Sort of like invitations from the city of Chemnitz. We did this three years ago, I swam 620 km down the Elbe and now the Danube is on the schedule. We always swam between eight and ten hours a day in the Elbe, and I would do the same on the Danube. I hope that this will be possible in 2022. At the moment, I can't train at all because of the lockdown and there have also been other events recently that have kept me from doing it, e.g. the wedding, the house or the promotion. There is a small long-distance swimming community in Germany where all the people know each other. During the swim, you also always have companions looking out for you, so nothing can happen to you."

Seit dem 01.09. arbeite ich als Bufdi im Umweltzentrum, kÃ¼mmere mich dort in erster Linie um die Ãffentlichkeitsarbeit und helfe nebenbei Ã¼berall dort aus, wo sonst noch Hilfe gebraucht wird. So habe ich schon an ein paar Projekten zum Pflanzen zÃ¤hlen und auspflanzen teilgenommen und so lange es mÃ¶glich war, immer nachmittags beim Projekt âAlltag Neue Heimatâ viele interessante GesprÃ¤che mit Menschen aus aller Welt gefÃ¼hrt, die es aus den verschiedensten GrÃ¼nden nach Dresden verschlagen hat. Im Moment bin ich leider grÃ¶Ãtenteils im Homeoffice und viele dieser Projekte sind schwierig bis gar nicht umsetzbar.

Was mir an den TÃ¤tigkeiten im Umweltzentrum am meisten SpaÃ macht, ist die Arbeit an den ABC-Tischen, beim Projekt âAlltag Neue Heimatâ. Man lernt immer etwas dazu, quasi spielerisch nebenbei. Man unterhÃ¤lt sich, und am Anfang gibt es vielleicht ein paar Kommunikationsprobleme, aber das GesprÃ¤ch entwickelt sich ganz von selbst, wenn man das sprachliche Level gefunden hat, auf dem eine gute VerstÃ¤ndigung mÃ¶glich ist. Im Vergleich zu den vielen Anderen, die ehrenamtlich dort tÃ¤tig sind, fehlt mir noch die Routine und manchmal bin ich unsicher, ob ich es schaffe, allein ein GesprÃ¤ch anzustoÃen und am Leben zu erhalten. Aber wenn diese Angst Ã¼berwunden ist, klappt es am Ende doch meistens, und dann nimmt man immer etwas mit aus den GesprÃ¤chen. Ich habe schon so viel gelernt auf kultureller und gesellschaftlicher, aber auch auf emotionaler und persÃ¶nlicher Ebene. Dabei war ich gerade mal einen Monat regelmÃ¤Ãig dort.

An einem Nachmittag Ende Oktober, kurz vor der erneuten VerschÃ¤rfung der MaÃnahmen, habe ich mit einer Ehrenamtlichen und einem Mann aus Tunesien zwei Stunden lang Ã¼ber Geschichten aus der Bibel und die historische Entstehung Jerusalems geredet. Ich selbst bin weder getauft noch glÃ¤ubig, aber die beiden hatten so viel Hintergrundwissen, dass sie sowohl miteinander diskutieren als auch mir, dem Unwissenden, mit vereinten KrÃ¤ften alle mÃ¶glichen Fragen beantworten konnten. Ich habe so viel gelernt an diesem Nachmittag und finde es bis heute beeindruckend, wie gut und wie freundlich solch ein GesprÃ¤ch Ã¼ber ein heikles Thema wie Religion trotz des unterschiedlichen sprachlichen Levels, trotz unterschiedlicher Kultur und Herkunft und trotz unterschiedlicher Ansichten verlaufen kann.

Ein anderes Mal hatte ein syrisches MÃ¤dchen in meinem Alter von ihrer Flucht erzÃ¤hlt. Ich weiÃ nicht, ob man das als schÃ¶n bezeichnen kann. Aber es war sehr ergreifend, weil ich das erste Mal eine greifbare und bildliche Vorstellung von dem hatte, was Flucht bedeutet. Die Thematik Flucht ist ja an sich sehr prÃ¤sent und ich hatte schon ein gewisses Vorwissen. Aber irgendwie existierte das nur ganz abstrakt, basierend auf Zahlen und Nachrichten und objektiven Presseberichten. Erst dieses GesprÃ¤ch, der ganz persÃ¶nliche Erfahrungsbericht, hat das Problem fÃ¼r mich menschlich und emotional greifbar gemacht. Es ist schwer zu erklÃ¤ren, ich weiÃ nicht, ob man das versteht. Ich finde, dass jeder so ein GesprÃ¤ch einmal erleben sollte. Die Tische sind der beste Platz dafÃ¼r. Wenn der Lockdown vorbei ist, freue ich mich am meisten darauf, dass dieses Projekt weiter geht. Leider ist das im Moment ja noch nicht so sicher."

"I turned eighteen last year and graduated from the "GlÃ¼ck Auf" high school in Dippoldiswalde. Since September 1, I have been working as a volunteer at the Umweltzentrum, where I primarily handle public relations and help out wherever else help is needed. I have already participated in a few plant counting and planting projects and, as long as it was possible, I have always had many interesting conversations with people from all over the world who have come to Dresden for various reasons. At the moment, unfortunately, I am mostly working at home, and many of these projects are difficult or impossible to implement.

What I enjoy most about the activities at the environmental center is the work at the ABC tables, in the project "Everyday New Home". You always learn something new, almost playfully along the way. You talk to each other, and at the beginning there may be a few communication problems, but the conversation develops all of its own accord once you have found the linguistic level at which a good understanding is possible. Compared to the many others who volunteer there, it is not yet routine and sometimes I am unsure whether I will be able to initiate a conversation on my own and keep it alive. But once that fear is overcome, it usually works out in the end, and then you always take something away from the conversations. I have already learned so much on a cultural and social level, but also on an emotional and personal level. And I was only there regularly for one month.

One afternoon at the end of October, shortly before the measures were tightened again, I talked for two hours with a volunteer and a man from Tunisia about stories from the Bible and the historical origins of Jerusalem. I myself am neither baptized nor a believer, but the two of them had so much background knowledge that they were able to discuss with each other as well as answer all kinds of questions for me, the ignorant one, with their combined efforts. I learned so much that afternoon and to this day I find it impressive how well and how friendly such a conversation about a sensitive topic like religion can go despite the different language levels, despite different cultures and backgrounds, and despite different views.

Another time, a Syrian girl my age had told me about her escape. I don't know if you can call that nice. But it was very moving, because for the first time I had a tangible and visual idea of what fleeing means. The subject of fleeing is in itself very present and I already had a certain prior knowledge. But somehow it only existed in the abstract, based on numbers and news and objective press reports. It was only this conversation, this very personal account of her experience, that made the problem human and emotionally tangible for me. It's hard to explain, I don't know if you can understand it. I think everyone should experience such a conversation once. The tables are the best place for it. When the lockdown is over, I'm most looking forward to this project continuing. Unfortunately, that's not so sure at the moment."

Ich habe schon so viel gelernt auf kultureller und gesellschaftlicher, aber auch auf emotionaler und persÃ¶nlicher Ebene. Dabei war ich gerade mal einen Monat regelmÃ¤Ãig dort.

An einem Nachmittag Ende Oktober, kurz vor der erneuten VerschÃ¤rfung der MaÃnahmen, habe ich mit einer Ehrenamtlichen und einem Mann aus Tunesien zwei Stunden lang Ã¼ber Geschichten aus der Bibel und die historische Entstehung Jerusalems geredet. Ich selbst bin weder getauft noch glÃ¤ubig, aber die beiden hatten so viel Hintergrundwissen, dass sie sowohl miteinander diskutieren als auch mir, dem Unwissenden, mit vereinten KrÃ¤ften alle mÃ¶glichen Fragen beantworten konnten. Ich habe so viel gelernt an diesem Nachmittag und finde es bis heute beeindruckend, wie gut und wie freundlich solch ein GesprÃ¤ch Ã¼ber ein heikles Thema wie Religion trotz des unterschiedlichen sprachlichen Levels, trotz unterschiedlicher Kultur und Herkunft und trotz unterschiedlicher Ansichten verlaufen kann.

Ein anderes Mal hatte ein syrisches MÃ¤dchen in meinem Alter von ihrer Flucht erzÃ¤hlt. Ich weiÃ nicht, ob man das als schÃ¶n bezeichnen kann. Aber es war sehr ergreifend, weil ich das erste Mal eine greifbare und bildliche Vorstellung von dem hatte, was Flucht bedeutet. Die Thematik Flucht ist ja an sich sehr prÃ¤sent und ich hatte schon ein gewisses Vorwissen. Aber irgendwie existierte das nur ganz abstrakt, basierend auf Zahlen und Nachrichten und objektiven Presseberichten. Erst dieses GesprÃ¤ch, der ganz persÃ¶nliche Erfahrungsbericht, hat das Problem fÃ¼r mich menschlich und emotional greifbar gemacht. Es ist schwer zu erklÃ¤ren, ich weiÃ nicht, ob man das versteht. Ich finde, dass jeder so ein GesprÃ¤ch einmal erleben sollte. Die Tische sind der beste Platz dafÃ¼r. Wenn der Lockdown vorbei ist, freue ich mich am meisten darauf, dass dieses Projekt weiter geht. Leider ist das im Moment ja noch nicht so sicher."

"I turned eighteen last year and graduated from the "GlÃ¼ck Auf" high school in Dippoldiswalde. Since September 1, I have been working as a volunteer at the Umweltzentrum, where I primarily handle public relations and help out wherever else help is needed. I have already participated in a few plant counting and planting projects and, as long as it was possible, I have always had many interesting conversations with people from all over the world who have come to Dresden for various reasons. At the moment, unfortunately, I am mostly working at home, and many of these projects are difficult or impossible to implement.

What I enjoy most about the activities at the environmental center is the work at the ABC tables, in the project "Everyday New Home". You always learn something new, almost playfully along the way. You talk to each other, and at the beginning there may be a few communication problems, but the conversation develops all of its own accord once you have found the linguistic level at which a good understanding is possible. Compared to the many others who volunteer there, it is not yet routine and sometimes I am unsure whether I will be able to initiate a conversation on my own and keep it alive. But once that fear is overcome, it usually works out in the end, and then you always take something away from the conversations. I have already learned so much on a cultural and social level, but also on an emotional and personal level. And I was only there regularly for one month.

One afternoon at the end of October, shortly before the measures were tightened again, I talked for two hours with a volunteer and a man from Tunisia about stories from the Bible and the historical origins of Jerusalem. I myself am neither baptized nor a believer, but the two of them had so much background knowledge that they were able to discuss with each other as well as answer all kinds of questions for me, the ignorant one, with their combined efforts. I learned so much that afternoon and to this day I find it impressive how well and how friendly such a conversation about a sensitive topic like religion can go despite the different language levels, despite different cultures and backgrounds, and despite different views.

Another time, a Syrian girl my age had told me about her escape. I don't know if you can call that nice. But it was very moving, because for the first time I had a tangible and visual idea of what fleeing means. The subject of fleeing is in itself very present and I already had a certain prior knowledge. But somehow it only existed in the abstract, based on numbers and news and objective press reports. It was only this conversation, this very personal account of her experience, that made the problem human and emotionally tangible for me. It's hard to explain, I don't know if you can understand it. I think everyone should experience such a conversation once. The tables are the best place for it. When the lockdown is over, I'm most looking forward to this project continuing. Unfortunately, that's not so sure at the moment."

media.description:
"Ich hatte eine echt beschissene Vergangenheit hinter mir. Ich hatte jede MÃ¶glichkeit, die Sprache zu verkacken, die Schule genauso und mein Arbeitsleben noch dazu. In Deutschland das eigene Leben zu verkacken, kann so schnell gehen. Man hat alle MÃ¶glichkeiten, was man aus sich macht. Dieses Land ermÃ¶glicht jedem den Zugang zu jeder Art von den Drogen und gleichzeitig zu jeder Art von Erfolg.

Der erste Erfolg war die Sprache. Ich habe mich seit Tag eins fÃ¼r die Sprache interessiert. Ich wollte einfach endlich alles alleine erledigen kÃ¶nnen, die Frau ansprechen, die ich hÃ¼bsch finde, dahin zu gehen, wo ich will, ohne Hilfe von irgendjemandem zu brauchen, das zu erreichen, was mir SpaÃ macht. Dann folgte die Schule. Obwohl ich aus drei Schulen rausgeschmissen wurde, da ich einfach der Meinung war, dass ein Abschluss nicht mein Leben bestimmt, und ich fast jeden Tag die Schule geschwÃ¤nzt habe. Am Ende hatte ich alles einfach satt. Ich wollte einfach irgendeinen Abschluss machen und habe den Realschulabschluss mit einem Durchschnitt von 2,3 gemacht. Man muss kein Genie sein, um einen Abschluss zu haben, man muss die Sprache nicht perfekt sprechen, man braucht nur den Willen.

Vor Ã¼ber zweieinhalb Jahren habe ich mit MMA angefangen. Ich wusste damals Ã¼berhaupt nicht, was der Kampfsport mit einer Person machen kann. Wenn ich jetzt aber zurÃ¼ckblicke, sehe ich, dass der Kampfsport mich zu dem gemacht hat, der ich jetzt bin. Kampfsport als Hobby zu haben, kann das Leben einer Person um 180 Grad ins Positive Ã¤ndern. Man macht dadurch tÃ¤glich Sport, tÃ¤glich geht man an seine Grenzen, tÃ¤glich geht man nach Hause mit dem Gedanken: Heute bin ich besser geworden. Leider haben viele Menschen Angst davor, sowas auszuprobieren und trauen sich nicht, doch wenn sie es einmal probiert haben, werden sie sehen, dass so ein Sport ein respektvoller Sport ist, bei dem man in jeder Trainingseinheit Vollgas gibt, um voranzukommen. Wenn man das tagtÃ¤glich erlebt, zieht das automatisch in das private Leben ein und man fÃ¤ngt an, nicht nur sportlich besser zu werden sondern auch im Leben! 

Fast das volle Selbstbewusstsein, das ich jetzt habe, entstand durch den Kampfsport. Ich hatte jeden Tag, zweieinhalb Jahre lang tÃ¤glich mindestens eine Trainingseinheit. Ich gebe zu, dass ich ohne Kampfsport ich an verschiedenen Punkten aufgehÃ¶rt hÃ¤tte, doch nur der, der viel Sport treibt, weiÃ, dass man sich nach jeder Trainingseinheit so gut fÃ¼hlt, dass man danach all die Probleme in Ruhe angehen kann, da das Gehirn dafÃ¼r in dem Moment wieder fÃ¤hig ist. Sucht euch einen Sport, der euch voranbringt. Wenn er euch Freude schenkt und ihr dadurch kÃ¶rperlich fitter werdet, dann ist das nicht mehr Sport, sondern ein Hobby. 

Seitdem ich 17 war, habe ich mich mit der Thematik SelbststÃ¤ndigkeit beschÃ¤ftigt. Am Anfang war es nur eine Idee. Mehr als die HÃ¤lfte der Leute hat mich mit einem LÃ¤cheln angeschaut - als ob es nie im Leben ein Syrer geschafft hat, sich mit 18 Jahren selbststÃ¤ndig zu machen. Ich habe jede dieser Personen ausgelacht und die Idee trotzdem umgesetzt. Ich habe mich Anfang 2020 im Finanz- und Immobilienvertrieb selbststÃ¤ndig gemacht und spÃ¤ter als freiberuflicher Dolmetscher angefangen. Mit den beiden Berufen verdiene ich einen Haufen Geld, viel zu viel Ã¼ber dem Durchschnitt. Sowas als Syrer zu erleben ist selten, doch man muss nur an sich glauben und man schafft alles."

Teil 2/2
--
"I had a really shitty past behind me. I had every opportunity to mess up the language, school as well, and my working life to boot. Screwing up your life in Germany can happen so quickly. You have all the opportunities to choose what you make of yourself. This country gives everyone access to every kind of the drugs and at the same time to every kind of success.

The first success was the language. I was interested in the language since day one. I just wanted to finally be able to do everything on my own, to approach the woman I think is pretty, to go where I want without needing help from anyone, to achieve what is fun for me. Then came school. I got kicked out of three schools because I just felt that a degree didn't define my life, and I skipped school almost every day. In the end, I just got tired of everything. I just wanted to get some kind of degree, and I graduated from Realschule with a 2.3 average. You don't have to be a genius to have a degree, you don't have to speak the language perfectly, you just need the will.

I started doing MMA over two and a half years ago. At that time, I didn't know at all what the martial arts could do to a person. But now when I look back, I see that martial arts made me who I am now. Having martial arts as a hobby can change a person's life 180 degrees to the positive. It makes you exercise every day, it makes you push yourself to your limits every day, and it makes you go home thinking, "Today I got better." Unfortunately, a lot of people are afraid to try something like this, but once they try it, they will see that it is a respectful sport, where you push yourself hard in every training session to progress. When you experience that on a daily basis, it automatically moves into your personal life, and you start to get better not only athletically but in life as well!

Almost all of the self-confidence I have now came from martial arts. I had at least one training session every day, every day for two and a half years. I admit that without martial arts I would have stopped at various points, but only the people who do a lot of sports know that after each training session you feel so good that afterwards you can tackle all the problems in peace, because your brain is capable of it again at that moment. Look for a sport that moves you forward. If it gives you pleasure and makes you physically fitter, then it's no longer a sport, it's a hobby.

Since I was 17, I've been thinking about self-employment. In the beginning it was just an idea. More than half of the people looked at me with a smile - as if no Syrian had ever managed to start his own business at the age of 18. I laughed at each of these people and implemented the idea anyway. I started my own business in finance and real estate sales in early 2020 and later started as a freelance interpreter. With the two professions, I make a bunch of money, way too much above average. To experience something like this as a Syrian is rare, but you just have to believe in yourself and you can do anything."

Part 2/2

"Ich bin in Dresden geboren, hier aufgewachsen, zur Schule und in die Uni gegangen. Ich habe mit einem Jahr Pause immer hier gelebt und gearbeitet. Als Reisebloggerin und Autorin von ReisefÃ¼hrern zum Thema Neuseeland-Reisen mit Kind bin ich ziemlich erfolgreich geworden. Reisen und darÃ¼ber schreiben war in den letzten fÃ¼nfzehn Jahren mein Leben, mit dem ich ziemlich zufrieden war. Das heiÃt nicht, dass wir in Saus und Braus gelebt haben, aber wir konnten uns mit unseren drei Kindern prinzipiell alle ReisetrÃ¤ume erfÃ¼llen, die wir so hatten. Das empfinde ich als groÃen Luxus - und wenn danach nix mehr Ã¼brig ist, dann ist das halt so.

Anfang 2020 war mit dem schÃ¶nen Leben dann Schluss, weil niemand mehr nach Neuseeland reisen konnte. Das war fÃ¼r mich ein ziemlicher Schock, aber auch ein Schubs - ich hatte nÃ¤mlich schon seit lÃ¤ngerem ein immer schlechteres Gewissen, anderen Familien Fernreisen zu empfehlen, die man aus Klimaschutz-GrÃ¼nden eigentlich gar nicht mehr machen dÃ¼rfte. Das gÃ¤rte seit 2019 in mir, dem Jahr, als wir so oft demonstrieren waren wie noch nie. Nicht nur mit Fridays for Future, sondern auch mit Herz statt Hetze. Das Jahr war fÃ¼r mich so eine Art politisches Erwachen - und ich schÃ¤me mich ein bisschen, dass das so lange gedauert hat. Ich habe mich als Wahlhelferin bei der Stadtratswahl gemeldet, war bei Klima-Aktionen von Campact dabei und engagiere mich seit Anfang 2020 ehrenamtlich fÃ¼r die Woche des guten Lebens - eine Woche ohne Autos in der ÃuÃeren Neustadt.

Seit wir vor zwe iJahren einen schweren Unfall hatten, bei dem zum GlÃ¼ck nur das Auto geschrottet wurde, leben wir autofrei und sind selbst Ã¼berrascht, wie gut das geht. 2019 habe ich dann auch meinen ersten Dresden-ReisefÃ¼hrer fÃ¼r Familien geschrieben - und meine Heimatstadt, in der ich seit Ã¼ber vierzig Jahren lebe, noch einmal ganz neu kennen und lieben gelernt. Man kÃ¶nnte fast sagen, dass mich meine neu entdeckte Heimatliebe durch die Corona-Krise getragen hat. Einerseits hatten wir auch im ersten Lockdown schon genug Ausflugstipps in der Umgebung durch meine Recherchen und ich habe den Fokus meines Blogs erfolgreich auf Regional verschoben. Andererseits hat es mir auch psychisch geholfen, weil ich mit der Woche des guten Lebens immer etwas habe, das ich klimapolitisch superwichtig finde und fÃ¼r das ich ganz persÃ¶nlich etwas tun kann. Das fÃ¼hlt sich noch besser an, als in einer groÃen Menge dicht an dicht auf einer autofreien StraÃe zu laufen und Slogans zu rufen. Und es ist auf jeden Fall besser als auf der Couch zu hocken und sich machtlos zu fÃ¼hlen, am Zustand der Welt etwas Ã¤ndern zu kÃ¶nnen.

Eigentlich war die Woche des guten Lebens fÃ¼r September 2020 geplant, musste aber wie so vieles andere wegen der Pandemie verschoben werden. Aktuell sind wir fleiÃig am Entwerfen von Kampagnen, um die NeustÃ¤dter*innen darÃ¼ber zu informieren, was auf sie zukommt, was sie erwarten dÃ¼rfen, aber vor allem, wie sie sich beteiligen kÃ¶nnen. Denn der Sinn dieses Verkehrsexperiments ist es zu schauen, was die Menschen mit autofreien StraÃen machen - wie sie sie nutzen, wie sie sich dabei fÃ¼hlen und ob sie dadurch ihr MobilitÃ¤tsverhalten Ã¤ndern. In der Neustadt haben eh nur etwa zwanzig Prozent der Anwohnenden ein eigenes Auto, und trotzdem sind die schÃ¶nen StraÃen immer verstopft. Ich bin total gespannt, was sich da entwickeln wird, wenn die StraÃenrÃ¤nder mal frei von Blech sind. Ich hoffe sehr, dass die Woche des guten Lebens ohne erneute Corona-EinschrÃ¤nkungen stattfinden kann und dass sehr viele Anwohnende sich beteiligen. Ich hoffe, dass dabei vielen Menschen klar werden wird, wie lebenswert eine autofreie Stadt sein kann - und dass sich diese Erkenntnis bis in den Stadtrat durchsetzt. Ich hoffe natÃ¼rlich vor allem, dass wir wie versprochen bis zum Sommer alle unsere Impfung gegen Corona bekommen und dann endlich wieder guten Gewissens und ohne Angst verreisen kÃ¶nnen. Das fehlt mir inzwischen schon sehr - dabei will ich ja gar nicht, wie ursprÃ¼nglich mal geplant war, nach Neuseeland fahren. Die Ostsee, Slowenien oder Portugal reichen schon."

"I was born in Dresden, grew up here, and went to school and university here. I have always lived and worked here with a one-year gap. I became quite successful as a travel blogger and author of travel guides on the subject of traveling in New Zealand travel with children. Traveling and writing about it has been my life for the last fifteen years, and I've been pretty happy with it. That doesn't mean we've been living the high life, but with our three children we've basically been able to fulfill any travel dreams we've had. I consider that a great luxury - and if there's nothing left after that, then that's just the way it is.

At the beginning of 2020, the good life came to an end because no one could travel to New Zealand anymore. That was quite a shock for me, but also a push - I'd had an increasingly guilty conscience for some time now, for recommending long-distance travel to other families, which you shouldn't do anymore for climate protection reasons. This had been fermenting in me since 2019, the year when we demonstrated more often than ever before. Not only with Fridays for Future, but also with Herz statt Hetze. The year was a kind of political awakening for me - and I'm a little ashamed that it took so long. I volunteered as an election worker in the city council elections, took part in Campact's climate actions, and have been volunteering for the Week of Good Living since the beginning of 2020 - a week without cars in the ÃuÃere Neustadt.

Since we had a serious accident two years ago, in which fortunately only the car was damaged, we have been living car-free and are surprised ourselves how well it works. In 2019, I also wrote my first Dresden travel guide for families - and got to know and love my hometown, where I have lived for over forty years, all over again. You could almost say that my newfound love of home carried me through the Corona crisis. On the one hand, even in the first lockdown, we already had enough trip tips in the area through my research and I successfully shifted the focus of my blog to regional. On the other hand, it also helped me psychologically because with the Week of Good Living, I have something that I think is super important in terms of climate policy and that I can do something about personally. That feels even better than walking in a big crowd close together on a car-free street shouting slogans. And it's definitely better than sitting on the couch and feeling powerless to change anything about the state of the world.

Actually, the Week of Good Living was planned for September 2020, but like so many other things, it had to be postponed because of the pandemic. Currently, we are busy designing campaigns to inform the people in the Neustadt about what is in store for them, what they can expect, but most importantly, how they can participate. After all, the point of this traffic experiment is to see what people do with car-free streets - how they use them, how they feel about them, and whether they change their travel patterns as a result. At the beginning of 2020, the good life came to an end because no one could travel to New Zealand anymore. That was quite a shock for me, but also a push - I'd had an increasingly guilty conscience for some time now, for recommending long-distance travel to other families, which you shouldn't do anymore for climate protection reasons. This had been fermenting in me since 2019, the year when we demonstrated more often than ever before. Not only with Fridays for Future, but also with Herz statt Hetze. "I am from Dresden; I was born here, grew up here and went to school here. I wanted to get a breath of foreign air, but somehow ended up stuck here. I studied German as a foreign language, which allowed me to combine the outside world and the inside world. I studied in London, did my internship in Kiev as part of my studies, and later traveled again to Montpellier.

But Kazakhstan surprised me the most. I felt incredibly comfortable there. The people there were incredibly pleasant. They welcomed me with open arms. I had the feeling that not so many people have the country on their agenda. If you know it, it's through the movie Borat, which doesn't show the best features of the country. People were incredibly open, but also sensitive enough to see when you wanted to be left alone. I always thought that was European openness coupled with Asian restraint.

I work at the TU Dresden in a project in which refugees are prepared for their university studies. I teach German. In addition, I worked for Boston University for many years. The work is great fun, and has enormous challenges. I think we've got a good handle on switching to digital teaching. In the last year, I've learned a lot, especially about digital teaching. The project is not only about teaching, but also about preparing students for their everyday university life. The worlds, the perceptions are different. That's natural, because everyone has a different learning tradition. Sometimes there is a clash, which is actually not bad, because that's how misunderstandings come to light.
As a rule, in my professional field, being permanently employed is very rare. It's usually the case that almost only honorarium contracts are issued. These are not very good conditions. I often find that the training and the profession are not very well recognized, and teachers are asked to work for a very low hourly rate, without the need for training.

Many refugees have the desire to study because it is a fixed idea for them. However, they hardly know what is involved. In some cases, they only know about studying from their home countries. But they hardly have any idea of how studying works in the German system. How could they? With us, they are in a protected space, we organize a lot for them, and they are also otherwise financed by DAAD and public funds. There are many participants who are motivated, who have also had a lot of obstacles. The reasons are many and varied: We have Turkish families who have come to Germany with their children and are starting a new life here. There are Syrian refugees who are very affected by the events in their country. But we also have participants from other Arab countries who are in Germany for a variety of reasons. But all of them have many experiences that were very formative.

It is nice to see when participants have managed to pass their German language entrance exam and are now allowed to study. For many, that was a hard piece of work. But some fail because they have problems in perceiving their problems. Some take the easy on themselves and point to the course instructor and think that he or she is responsible for their success. They rarely see that we support them and help them.

It is not only the salary issue that shows that the work is so poorly valued. Many people can' t imagine what is involved. Every course is different. Although you build up a certain repertoire of materials over time, for each day of class I have at least two hours of preparation and also follow-up. That means I think about how best to convey the material, what exercises might go with it, come up with assignments, and monitor performance, which has to be checked regularly through various tests. That's a lot of work. It's fun, though. I'm one of the lucky ones at the moment who have a fixed-term contract, but there are an incredible number who work on a fee basis who don't have that luck. At the moment - as with many due to the pandemic - the rates are cut, and they earn a minimum, from which they have to finance one hundred percent of the social contributions, taxes and pension. We do not have a social security fund for artists. If you look at it that way, you are working for zero euros. There are many ambitious and qualified lecturers who teach because they enjoy it. It only works because of their motivation. Many don't see the effort behind it, the time that is spent. Yes, the companies want to make money, but in some cases it is really borderline in terms of how the instructors are treated. My friend, who like me is a lecturer for DaF, sent me an ad on Saturday from a school that is looking for teachers, for 16 â¬ an hour. This is disastrous!

I hope that we will get through this situation okay - that we will somehow get back to normality, whatever it looks like. This time will have a very formative effect on us and our society, and I'm curious to see how. I hope people will stay sane and see the seriousness of the situation we are in, put the "I" aside and pay more attention to the "we". I wish to be able to breathe the sea air or mountain air again. I wish I could get on a plane again without worrying about it and discover new things. But most of all, I wish for good health.

That's natural, because everyone has a different learning tradition. Sometimes there is a clash, which is actually not bad, because that's how misunderstandings come to light.
As a rule, in my professional field, being permanently employed is very rare. It's usually the case that almost only honorarium contracts are issued. These are not very good conditions. I often find that the training and the profession are not very well recognized, and teachers are asked to work for a very low hourly rate, without the need for training.

Many refugees have the desire to study because it is a fixed idea for them. However, they hardly know what is involved. In some cases, they only know about studying from their home countries. But they hardly have any idea of how studying works in the German system. How could they? With us, they are in a protected space, we organize a lot for them, and they are also otherwise financed by DAAD and public funds. There are many participants who are motivated, who have also had a lot of obstacles. The reasons are many and varied: We have Turkish families who have come to Germany with their children and are starting a new life here. There are Syrian refugees who are very affected by the events in their country. But we also have participants from other Arab countries who are in Germany for a variety of reasons. But all of them have many experiences that were very formative.

It is nice to see when participants have managed to pass their German language entrance exam and are now allowed to study. For many, that was a hard piece of work. But some fail because they have problems in perceiving their problems. Some take the easy on themselves and point to the course instructor and think that he or she is responsible for their success. They rarely see that we support them and help them.

It is not only the salary issue that shows that the work is so poorly valued. Many people can' t imagine what is involved. Every course is different. Although you build up a certain repertoire of materials over time, for each day of class I have at least two hours of preparation and also follow-up. That means I think about how best to convey the material, what exercises might go with it, come up with assignments, and monitor performance, which has to be checked regularly through various tests. That's a lot of work. It's fun, though. I'm one of the lucky ones at the moment who have a fixed-term contract, but there are an incredible number who work on a fee basis who don't have that luck. At the moment - as with many due to the pandemic - the rates are cut, and they earn a minimum, from which they have to finance one hundred percent of the social contributions, taxes and pension. We do not have a social security fund for artists. If you look at it that way, you are working for zero euros. There are many ambitious and qualified lecturers who teach because they enjoy it. It only works because of their motivation. Many don't see the effort behind it, the time that is spent. Yes, the companies want to make money, but in some cases it is really borderline in terms of how the instructors are treated. My friend, who like me is a lecturer for DaF, sent me an ad on Saturday from a school that is looking for teachers, for 16 â¬ an hour. This is disastrous!

I hope that we will get through this situation okay - that we will somehow get back to normality, whatever it looks like. This time will have a very formative effect on us and our society, and I'm curious to see how. I hope people will stay sane and see the seriousness of the situation we are in, put the "I" aside and pay more attention to the "we". I wish to be able to breathe the sea air or mountain air again. I wish I could get on a plane again without worrying about it and discover new things. But most of all, I wish for good health.

"I have lived in Dresden since I began my training to become nurse. Now I am studying medicine, and I am almost finished. "Itâs important to me that I feel safe. At the moment, I have the feeling that there is too much aggression here. The propensity to violence has been rising recently. I donât know why. I donât want to say that itâs more from the foreigners. I have the feeling that at certain places in Dresden â especially when alcohol is flowing â the propensity to violence grows.

But itâs not just alcohol. Sometimes, I have the feeling that a lot of people are frustrated because they are unemployed and then imagine that if a guy comes from work and has a beer during their evening off, that itâs his fault that they donât have work. But if you look around in Dresden â every second company is looking for someone. But people donât want to leave the house at three or four in the morning. I like donât like the attitude, especially with young people. They have the opinion, âI would rather sleep until twelve, get Hartz IV, let the government pay my rent and get out of paying media taxes.â That annoys me because they donât have the pride to say, âNo, I am not going to depend on the state.â

I have to say something, which a lot of people wonât believe since I was recently attacked by foreigners: I have nothing against foreigners in general. They behave themselves and work and say themselves that they are ashamed of their compatriots.

Like with me â they see that you go to the bank and then suddenly you get hit over the head. You canât remember anything at all, and they say to themselves that a human life is worth forty euros. "Itâs important to me that I feel safe. At the moment, I have the feeling that there is too much aggression here. The propensity to violence has been rising recently. I donât know why. I donât want to say that itâs more from the foreigners. I have the feeling that at certain places in Dresden â especially when alcohol is flowing â the propensity to violence grows.

But itâs not just alcohol. Sometimes, I have the feeling that a lot of people are frustrated because they are unemployed and then imagine that if a guy comes from work and has a beer during their evening off, that itâs his fault that they donât have work. But if you look around in Dresden â every second company is looking for someone. But people donât want to leave the house at three or four in the morning. I like donât like the attitude, especially with young people. They have the opinion, âI would rather sleep until twelve, get Hartz IV, let the government pay my rent and get out of paying media taxes.â That annoys me because they donât have the pride to say, âNo, I am not going to depend on the state.â

I was raised differently. I see it from a social perspective. I pay taxes like I should, but I also have to achieve something. Thatâs how our state feeds its self. Especially because we have the integration program, taxes need to be earned so that we can help the foreigners.

I have to say something, which a lot of people wonât believe since I was recently attacked by foreigners: I have nothing against foreigners in general. I have something against those who drink beer here and misbehave, insult our people. Thatâs a couple people unfortunately; but a lot of them work, including in my company. They behave themselves and work and say themselves that they are ashamed of their compatriots.

Like with me â they see that you go to the bank and then suddenly you get hit over the head. You canât remember anything at all, and they say to themselves that a human life is worth forty euros. We are getting afraid that at some point, something even more terrible happens. Before, I walked through the residential area more self-confidently. Everyone knew that I worked as a park gardener. Everyone had respect for me â âyou leave him alone, you donât touch him.â Recently, people come here, they drink three or four beers, then they drink hard alcohol and you can tell that they canât handle the hard alcohol. They are peaceful with beer, but with hard alcohol, they get super aggressive.

VONOVIA is forced to take foreigners. Like I said, I have nothing against foreigners. You have three classes: unemployed, employed and the integration patients. The integration patients are used to â I donât know if itâs because of their religion â sleeping during the day. But at night, they are loud. I come home from work, and I canât sleep. My employer says that I am not rested, I canât work well. I have stress at work. And the landlord says, âwe canât do anything.â They arenât responsible for security on site. The police just take the names down. There are also nice people with whom you can talk, but there are also those who drink beer and say, âwhat do you want, Nazi?â I see a propensity to violence, aggression, and no understanding. "Als 2015 so viele meiner Landsleute nach Deutschland gekommen sind, war das fuÌr mich uÌberraschend. Ich habe mich direkt bei den Maltesern und Johannitern als ehrenamtlicher Helfer gemeldet, bin in die UnterkuÌnfte gegangen und habe Workshops organisiert, auch fuÌr die MitarbeiterInnen. Meine Eltern sind zuhause und wollen Syrien nicht verlassen. In Hama gab es keine KaÌmpfe. Die Stadt ist von einer Million auf drei Millionen Einwohner gewachsen. Alles ist teurer geworden. ElektrizitaÌt ist knapp. Viele Familien sind auf Hilfe von AngehoÌrigen im Ausland angewiesen.

Ich habe mich nie mit den FluÌchtlingen verglichen. Jeder ist mit einem Ziel nach Deutschland gekommen. Ich bin gekommen mit dem Ziel, die Sprache zu lernen und so schnell wie moÌglich mit dem Studium anzufangen, um etwas zu erreichen. Ich darf auch nicht zuruÌck, weil ich dann zum MilitaÌr muss; die wollten einfach abhauen, damit sie nicht in die Armee muÌssen und so weiter. Das ist nicht zu vergleichen. Ich sehe, welche Probleme die GefluÌchteten mit der Anerkennung ihrer AbschluÌsse und mit den deutschen Standards haben. Die Deutschen sagen: âWir wollen unbedingt, dass derjenige oder diejenige unseren Abschluss hat.â Es reicht nicht, wenn man in Syrien Friseur war.  Man muss das hier wieder nachweisen oder die Ausbildung wiederholen. Die Leute haben aber erst mal Probleme mit ihren Sprachkenntnissen. Jemand, der mit 18 die Sprache lernt, hat andere QualitaÌten als jemand, der mit 40 die Sprache lernt."

Teil 2 von 2
--
"When so many of my fellow Syrians came to Germany in 2015, it was a surprise to me. I registered directly with the Malteser and Johanniter as a volunteer helper, went to the shelters and organized workshops, also for the staff. My parents are at home and don't want to leave Syria. There was no fighting in Hama. The city and has grown from one million to three million inhabitants. Everything has become more expensive. Electricity is scarce. Many families rely on help from relatives abroad.

I have never compared myself to the refugees. Everyone has come to Germany with a goal. I came with the goal of learning the language and starting my studies as soon as possible in order to achieve something. I'm not allowed to go back either, because then I'd have to join the military; they wanted to flee so they wouldn't have to join the army and so on. There is no comparison. I see the problems that refugees have with the recognition of their degrees and with German standards. They say "we absolutely want them to have our degrees." It's not enough to have been a hairdresser in Syria. You have to prove it again here or repeat the training. First of all, people have problems with language skills. Someone who learns the language at 18 has different qualities than someone who learns the language at 40."

"I am from Syria, I am 21 and I have been in Dresden with my family since 2015. I went to school here and now I am preparing for university. I still like Dresden because it's a quiet city and not so big that you get lost. I just feel comfortable here.

In the beginning it was very interesting for me. After all, it's a completely different culture. It was difficult, of course, because it's two completely different cultures. The food is different, the habits are different, the jokes are also different. That's why I was homesick at the beginning and felt strange here. I had to learn a lot about how to best get to know the culture. I was very curious and wanted to acquire a lot of new knowledge as quickly as possible.
Today I am very proud of myself, of everything I have accomplished. I feel like I am at home and I am very contented. I have found friends here that I can call "real friends" who have taught me a lot. There were always difficulties and there always will be, that's how I was able to become more self-confident. Before I came to Germany, I had very little self-confidence and was always insecure. Because of everything I have experienced here, I am more confident and I know that I can rely on myself.

I want to study medicine, even though it is hard and demanding. But that was and still is my goal. And it is also one of the reasons why I decided to study in Germany. You can't study medicine, what you learn during your studies, anywhere like you can in Germany. I hope that I will become a successful and very good doctor in the future and that I will be able to help a lot of people, get to know many other cultures and visit many new countries and gain new experiences. I also hope that the situation in my home country Syria will get better again; life there has just become so difficult from all sides and people have a hard time living there. That's why I hope that things will get better again. I hope that we will all survive these difficult times through which each of us would be affected. The main thing is not to give up hope and always think positively about the future.

In Germany, I have had so many opportunities that I could not have gotten in my home country. I worked in a dental practice where I met very friendly and nice people who also became friends. I did internships in a hospital and a kindergarten, I worked as an interpreter for people who don't know the language very well, and I worked at Svarovski. I learned a new language, visited new countries and met new people. All this has increased my self-confidence, changed my way of thinking and brought me a lot of new knowledge. I am very grateful for that.

We learned many things because of this pandemic. Many things that we had not appreciated, we miss today and we have only now perceived their importance. In the end, it seems to me that the most important thing you can have is health. I wish that someday we will return to our normal life, have these little things like going out and meeting friends, sitting in a cafe, or even flying somewhere again. Of course, the most important thing is that we all stay healthy."

"I am from Syria, I am 21 and I have been in Dresden with my family since 2015. I went to school here and now I am preparing for university. I still like Dresden because it's a quiet city and not so big that you get lost. I just feel comfortable here.

Hierher zu kommen, war schwierig fÃ¼r meinen Vater, aber fÃ¼r mich war es einfacher, weil ich ein Visum durch Nachzug bekommen konnte. NatÃ¼rlich gab es auch einige Schwierigkeiten, weil ich viele Dokumente brauchte und ich zur deutschen Botschaft in Beirut musste, denn es gibt keine deutschen Botschaft in Syrien.

""Art belongs to everyone and to no one. Art belongs to all time and no time. Art belongs to those who create it and to those who enjoy it. Art no more belongs to the people and the party than it once belonged to the nobility and the patrons. Art is the whisper of history heard through the din of time." So wrote Julian Barnes in his novel "The Noise of Time," and so I would like to describe about my relationship to the greatest art in the world - language.

My mother gave me the name that you often hear in Russian folk tales and that you often encounter in Russian stores on the chocolate bar, namely Alyona (ÐÐ»ÑÐ½Ð°). Pronounced in Russian, the name sounds much more authentic, of course, but the German alphabet unfortunately does not know the great letter "Ñ". This makes it all the more magical when this "Ñ", to which a monument has even been dedicated in the Russian city of Ulyanovsk, Lenin's hometown, is articulated by a native speaker.
As you may have noticed, I come from a great country, known by many natural as well as cultural features, world-famous for the wooden doll Matryoshka, the sounds of balalaika, deep lakes, wide forests and the austere character of its inhabitants. And I'm glad when I don't have to fight against prejudices here, because there are enough of them.

The fact that in 2015 people were standing on the streets of beautiful Dresden and one could observe, among other things, the waving Russian flag, really did not make it easier for me and my heart cramped in my body. Thanks to my upbringing and my openness to the world, I did not become a supporter of the dictatorial regime. Now I am glad that I can openly discuss with all students in my seminars at the university.
I was born at the crossroads of two different images of Russia: the Soviet Union and the newborn Russian Federation. The 90's brought not only the new hope and freedom of press as well as opinion, but also a lot of sadness, poverty and the feeling of insecurity to many families.

Thanks to my mother and my grandfather, who was a talented physicist and worked in the space industry, I got a good education and was able to enjoy a carefree and happy childhood with three scoops of chocolate ice cream and a glass of orange juice on weekends.

I studied German language and literature and until I was 23 I lived on the left side of the beautiful Volga River, in the city of Samara, which served as the third capital during the war and is home to Stalin's bunker, has one of the most beautiful waterfronts and a heritage influenced by many cultures.

Thanks to my work at the Center of German Culture in Russia, thanks to my first studies at Samara State University and second studies at TU Dresden, I was lucky enough to participate in many projects. As a result, I met many excellent people who came from all corners of the world and whose languages sounded so beautiful. Language, the language, a language, my language, your language ... is a key to human communication. Written language or spoken language is used everywhere. This is where I thrive, because I can think and speak freely in all the languages I know. This is my treasure trove, the treasures of which I gladly share with all other people."

"Ich komme aus dem Jemen und bin in 2016 nach Deutschland gekommen. Ich bin 24 Jahre alt. Ich bin Musiker, ich schreibe meine eigene Musik und verÃ¶ffentliche sie im Internet. 2019 bin ich nach Dresden umgezogen, weil ich die Stadt liebe. Sie ist weder zu groÃ noch zu klein. Auch die MÃ¶glichkeit fÃ¼r Musiker, auf der StraÃe Musik zu spielen, war eines der Dinge, die mich hierher gebracht haben. Die Leute hier unterstÃ¼tzen Musiker und ich hatte hier in Dresden endlich das GefÃ¼hl, angekommen zu sein.

Seit Beginn der Pandemie ist es schwierig. Musik auf der StraÃe zu spielen ist nicht mehr erlaubt. Konzerte sind auch nicht mÃ¶glich. Als Musiker ist es momentan ein bisschen schwierig, mit der Situation umzugehen. Zum GlÃ¼ck bekomme ich finanzielle UnterstÃ¼tzung vom Jobcenter, bis das vorbei ist.
Ich wÃ¼rde gerne wieder Musik auf der StraÃe spielen, weil ich das sehr vermisse. Und ich wÃ¼rde auch gerne auf kleinen Konzerten spielen. Ich plane auch, durch Deutschland zu reisen und meine Musik mit Menschen zu teilen. Das Schwierigste im Moment ist, nicht in der Lage zu sein, Leute zu treffen, zumal das Networking mit Musikern fÃ¼r mich wirklich wichtig ist. Ich vermisse die Interaktion mit Menschen und die MÃ¶glichkeit, Musik vor einem echten Publikum zu spielen.

Der Lockdown macht es schwierig, mich inspirieren zu lassen, neue Musik zu schreiben und zu machen. Trotz der Schwierigkeiten aufgrund des Lockdowns habe ich es aber geschafft, ein neues Lied zu schreiben. Ich bin froh darÃ¼ber, dass ich letzten Freitag diesen Song (IN MY MIND) endlich verÃ¶ffentlicht habe. Ich habe in den letzten vier Monaten daran gearbeitet.
Ich bin dankbar dafÃ¼r, hier in Deutschland zu sein, besonders in Dresden. Deutschland hat mir viele TÃ¼ren geÃ¶ffnet und dafÃ¼r bin ich dankbar. Es war am Anfang schwierig fÃ¼r mich, mich an alles hier zu gewÃ¶hnen, weil es eine andere Kultur und Sprache ist. Aber dann habe ich angefangen, Deutschland immer mehr zu lieben, und jetzt kann ich es mein Zuhause nennen."

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC8JcLPxNIOXaYhR5syxzM8w/featured
--
"I am from Yemen and came to Germany in 2016. I am 24 years old. I am a musician, I write my own music and publish it on the internet. I moved to Dresden in 2019 because I love the city. It is neither too big nor too small. Also, the opportunity for musicians to play music on the street was one of the things that brought me here. People here support musicians and I finally felt like I had arrived here in Dresden.

It's been difficult since the beginning of the pandemic. Playing music on the street is not allowed anymore. Concerts are also not possible. As a musician, it's a bit difficult to deal with the situation at the moment. Fortunately, I'm getting financial support from the Job Center until this is over.

I would like to play music on the street again, because I miss that a lot. And I would also like to play at small concerts. I also plan to travel around Germany and share my music with people. The hardest thing right now is not being able to meet people, since networking with musicians is really important to me. I miss interacting with people and being able to play music in front of a real audience.

The lockdown makes it difficult to get inspired to write and make new music. However, despite the difficulties due to the lockdown, I managed to write a new song. I'm happy to say that last Friday I finally released this song (IN MY MIND). I've been working on it for the past four months.

I'm grateful to be here in Germany, especially in Dresden. Germany has opened a lot of doors for me and I'm thankful for that. It was difficult for me in the beginning to get used to everything here because it's a different culture and language. But then I started to love Germany more and more and now I can call it my home."

"I am 29 years old and come from Iran. I have been in Germany for eight months. I have a bachelor's degree in financial management management and eleven years of experience in my profession.

Three years ago, my husband and I decided to emigrate to Germany. It was a very difficult decision for several reasons. In Tehran, we had our own apartment and our own car. I had an insurance office and my husband worked as an engineering computer scientist. We had to sell all our things in order to be able to continue our studies in Germany. We had researched various countries and finally decided on Germany. The reasons were the low inflation rate, democracy, free studies, purchasing power, low unemployment, the school system and environmental friendliness.

The German Embassy in Iran was overloaded, so I waited over two years for my visa. I got my visa, but they forgot or lost my husband's file. That's why my husband didn't have a visa. We couldn't live without each other, but my visa was only valid for three months, and I had to come to Germany.
Then Corona came. I wanted to fly to Berlin, but because of Corona my flight was cancelled. The German Embassy in Iran said that when my visa expires, I have to wait two years for my new visa. You can't imagine how bad that was for us. We had sold all our things. Because of high inflation, we couldn't buy them again.

My husband had hope, he sent over twenty emails to the airport police to get the Frankfurt airport police to let me in. My visa only had ten days left. I wanted to go to Frankfurt, but unfortunately Qatar Airways didn't let me in. They said there was a new law and even though I had a confirmation from Frankfurt, they were not allowed to carry me.

I came back home. I had given up, but my husband had not. He again wrote many emails to all the German airports describing my situation until Munich airport accepted me. The airport sent an email to Qatar Airways, authorizing me to fly to Munich. At that point, my visa still was still valid for three days. I would say never give up hope.

At the moment I have only one wish - to live together with my husband. At the moment the German Embassy is processing applications very slowly because of Corona.

I am happy with my new home. Contrary to what I had heard about Germans, they are very nice and friendly. Maybe I was just lucky. I would like to continue my studies and then work. About six months ago I found the ABC tables, which I am very happy about. When someone comes to Germany from abroad, he or she has many problems because he or she does not know the laws and culture. At the ABC tables they help you when you have a problem. They helped me a lot and were always empathetic. You learn the language and at the same time something about the culture. Also, I made a real friend there. I love him like my family. He is sensitive and kind and my best friend. I thank God very much that I met him."

"I am 29 years old and come from Iran. I have been in Germany for eight months. I have a bachelor's degree in financial management management and eleven years of experience in my profession.

Three years ago, my husband and I decided to emigrate to Germany. It was a very difficult decision for several reasons. In Tehran, we had our own apartment and our own car. I had an insurance office and my husband worked as an engineering computer scientist. We had to sell all our things in order to be able to continue our studies in Germany. We had researched various countries and finally decided on Germany. The reasons were the low inflation rate, democracy, free studies, purchasing power, low unemployment, the school system and environmental friendliness.

The German Embassy in Iran was overloaded, so I waited over two years for my visa. I got my visa, but they forgot or lost my husband's file. That's why my husband didn't have a visa. We couldn't live without each other, but my visa was only valid for three months, and I had to come to Germany.
Then Corona came. I wanted to fly to Berlin, but because of Corona my flight was cancelled. The German Embassy in Iran said that when my visa expires, I have to wait two years for my new visa. You can't imagine how bad that was for us. We had sold all our things. Because of high inflation, we couldn't buy them again.

My husband had hope, he sent over twenty emails to the airport police to get the Frankfurt airport police to let me in. My visa only had ten days left. I wanted to go to Frankfurt, but unfortunately Qatar Airways didn't let me in. They said there was a new law and even though I had a confirmation from Frankfurt, they were not allowed to carry me.

I came back home. I had given up, but my husband had not. He again wrote many emails to all the German airports describing my situation until Munich airport accepted me. The airport sent an email to Qatar Airways, authorizing me to fly to Munich. At that point, my visa still was still valid for three days. I would say never give up hope.

At the moment I have only one wish - to live together with my husband. At the moment the German Embassy is processing applications very slowly because of Corona.

I am happy with my new home. Contrary to what I had heard about Germans, they are very nice and friendly. Maybe I was just lucky. I would like to continue my studies and then work. About six months ago I found the ABC tables, which I am very happy about. When someone comes to Germany from abroad, he or she has many problems because he or she does not know the laws and culture. At the ABC tables they help you when you have a problem. They helped me a lot and were always empathetic. You learn the language and at the same time something about the culture. Also, I made a real friend there. I love him like my family. He is sensitive and kind and my best friend. I thank God very much that I met him."

"I had a car accident on the way to work thirteen years ago. There were six of us in the car. I lay in a coma for four days. I had to be resuscitated. The doctors only gave me a small chance to survive at all and if I did, with considerable damage. My partner visited me every day in the hospital. She had the idea of recording the voice of our daughter. She knew that I couldnât sleep through it when the baby cried and got up right away. She played it, and I woke up.

The driver died unfortunately. He was a good friend of mine, as old as my oldest son. It was pretty hard for me to bear. In 2013, I was lucky enough to be able to do trauma therapy here in the Uniklinik in Dresden. I waited for it for four years. The therapy helped me a lot. Up to that point, I had a lot of problems. It does a number on you when you have never been unemployed before.

In some respects, the accident made it difficult to be a father. I canât set limits. Because of the accident, I fell into a phase where I fell down psychologically and sometimes behaved like a child myself, didnât want to be treated â itâs difficult to describe. I let a lot of things slide. I didnât set boundaries; I didnât make announcements. I fell short of my role as a father. Itâs still difficult for me, although itâs been thirteen years. In some ways, itâs pretty complicated. Thatâs why we decided that we would separate, that I would get my own apartment, and find myself first.

I have discovered that the menâs network is stabilizing for me. I am around people and can speak normally, something that was incredibly difficult at first. For instance, the day clinic was difficult for me. I also went to meetup places for psychologically struggling people. It is difficult to find the right thing for yourself. Here in the menâs network, there is a workshop that I can use. Itâs good for me. I like to work with wood anyway, and I like to take on orders. I have now been here for a year, and itâs really fun. I take advantage of opportunities like todayâs foosball get-together or the menâs cafÃ©. That it is just men â thatâs the way it is. You can talk and exchange ideas about certain experiences, something that is really, really important. Some people would just like to talk, just want someone to listen. I notice that in myself, and I happily accept when someone comes to me and just speaks with me. There are some things that you canât do alone. Like when I got help from trained psychotherapists or like they helped me in the Uniklink, I am of the opinion that I also need help from professionals, who know what they are doing and can help me. And here in the menâs network, I have feeling that I can help other people. Just that alone helps."

âI am from Nigeria. I have been a doctor here in Germany, since 2015. I went to school in the Ukraine. I am currently practicing in Baden-Wurttemberg. My wife is doing her masterâs here in Dresden. I came to Germany from Nigeria to join her. â

âWe were introduced by a friend of a friend in the Ukraine. I am Latvian. I came to Dresden in 2011 to do my masterâs, and then I met my husband and we had two kids. I am currently on maternity leave, but I am planning on finishing my masterâs thesis soon. I am studying International Relations/International Law.â

âI am Muslim. Most of the people in the north of Nigeria are Muslim, but the country is mixed with Christians and people practicing traditional religion.â

âI was already a Muslim before I met him. I had converted before. âWhyâ is a long story. In Latvia, we are kind of religious, but not. We were occupied by the Soviets for 50 years, so religion was pretty much forbidden. The majority are atheists, but there are Catholics and Russian Orthodox. Christianity never spoke to me. I believed in God, but there was nothing in particular that made sense to me. Then I discovered Islam.

I studied politics, so I didnât believe everything the media told me, but I didnât really know anything about the religion. Only when I moved to Germany in 2011, I came into contact with Muslims, and it just made sense. After I did my research and everything, I converted. I met my husband about a year and a half later. And he was Muslim, so it all made sense. I know he wouldnât have considered me if I werenât Muslim. I maybe would have considered him.â

âI canât really say that I wouldnât have considered marrying her if she werenât Muslim. Maybe I would have said, âletâs see how it works out,â because I am quite an open person, but when it comes to family, someone you live with, you need to have a similar ideology. But I canât really say. There were other factors that came into it, not just our faith. Personal character.â
