"Als Kind war ich ein FlÃ¼chtling. Ich komme ursprÃ¼nglich aus Bosnien. Anfang der Neunziger ist meine Familie vor dem Krieg dort geflohen und nach Deutschland gekommen. Als wir hier ankamen war ich drei, und neun als ich zurÃ¼ck nach Bosnien musste. Damals hat der deutsche Staat gesagt, dass der Krieg vorbei ist und in unserem Heimatland keine Gefahr mehr herrscht, und meine Eltern haben sich entschieden, zurÃ¼ck zu gehen. Es gab Geschichten von anderen bosnischen Familien, die nachts von der Polizei abgeholt und zum Flughafen gebracht wurden. Meine Eltern dachten: âWir mussten bereits aus unserem Land flÃ¼chten; wir werden es nicht zulassen, dass unsere Kinder das noch einmal durchmachen mÃ¼ssen. Sie wollen, dass wir gehen, also gehen wir.â

Es war eine Katastrophe. Der Kontrast zu Deutschland war riesig. Der Krieg hatte gerade mal zwei Jahre vorher geendet. Das ganze Land war zerstÃ¶rt. Niemand hatte Geld. Alle waren sehr feindselig, besonders gegenÃ¼ber Leuten wie uns, die die Zeit des Krieges in Sicherheit verbracht hatten. Als ich in Deutschland war, hatte ich immer gedacht: âOk, hier bin ich jemand aus einem anderen Land, aber wenn ich zurÃ¼ckkomme, werde ich zu Hause sein. Sie werden uns als Landsleute willkommen heiÃen.â Aber es war dort viel schlimmer als hier.

Ich habe in Bosnien die Schule abgeschlossen und bin vor dreieinhalb Jahren nach Deutschland zurÃ¼ckgekehrt. Ich habe ein Stipendium bekommen und meinen Master in klinischer Psychologie und Psychotherapie an der TU Dresden begonnen. In meinem zweiten Semester kam auf einmal diese riesige Welle von FlÃ¼chtlingen nach Deutschland. Als jemand, der auch ein FlÃ¼chtling ist, hatte ich das BedÃ¼rfnis, etwas zu tun, den Leuten, die hier ankommen, zu helfen, aber ich wollte dabei meine Psychologiekenntnisse anwenden. Obwohl ich damals erst drei Jahre alt war, kann ich mich gut daran erinnern, wie meine Eltern gekÃ¤mpft haben als sie nach Deutschland gekommen sind. Zuerst ist man erleichtert, weil man in Sicherheit ist. Man ist weit weg von den Bomben und dem Krieg. Aber wenn man hierher kommt, kennt man niemanden, man kann die Sprache nicht. Man hat keine Mittel, um seine Ziele zu erreichen.

So ist die Idee entstanden, ein Partnerschaftsprogramm zwischen GeflÃ¼chteten und Psychologiestudenten aufzulegen. Die Idee ist, den GeflÃ¼chteten dabei zu helfen, positive und sinnvolle BeschÃ¤ftigungen zu finden. Der Mangel an sinnvollen TÃ¤tigkeiten ist etwas, das man einen âPostmigrationsstressorâ nennt. Wenn GeflÃ¼chtete eine BeschÃ¤ftigung und MÃ¶glichkeiten haben, ihre Ziele zu erreichen, verbessert sich ihr seelischer Zustand deutlich. Anderenfalls kÃ¶nnen diese Stressoren zu einer AbwÃ¤rtsspirale fÃ¼hren, was in einer Depression enden kann.

Wir bieten keine Therapie an. Wir konzentrieren uns nicht auf die Probleme der Vergangenheit; wir konzentrieren und auf das Hier und Jetzt und auf die Zukunft. Unser Ansatz basiert auf der Idee der LebensqualitÃ¤t, bei der man eine Skala mit verschiedenen Bereichen hat wie Familie, Hobbys, Religion oder SpiritualitÃ¤t. Wir fragen die Leute, wie wichtig ihnen die verschiedenen Bereiche sind und welche Ziele sie haben. So identifizieren wir die wichtigen Bereiche. Der zweite Schritt bei der Skala ist, dass die Person einschÃ¤tzt, inwieweit sie in diesen Bereichen ihre Ziele erreicht hat. Wir beobachten oft, dass die Leute die Zielerreichung in den fÃ¼r sie wichtigsten Zielen sehr niedrig einschÃ¤tzen, weil sie einfach keine Mittel haben. Im nÃ¤chsten Schritt suchen die Studenten AktivitÃ¤ten, die mit diesen Werten zu tun haben, um ihnen dabei zu helfen, ihre Ziele zu verfolgen.

Manchmal gibt es keine MÃ¶glichkeit, direkt etwas zu tun, dann suchen die Studenten nach AktivitÃ¤ten, die das Problem von einer anderen Seite angehen. Der GeflÃ¼chtete kann vielleicht seine Familie nicht erreichen, aber vielleicht kann er Arbeit finden, um Geld zu verdienen, das er ihnen schickt. Psychologiestudenten sind sehr empathisch und emotional intelligent, und sie versuchen, einen Weg zu finden zu helfen."

"When I was a child, I was a refugee. I am originally from Bosnia, and in the early 90s, my family fled the war there and came to Germany. I was three when I arrived here, and I was nine when I had to go back to Bosnia. At that point, the state of Germany said that the war was essentially over, there is no danger in our country, and my parents decided to go back. There were stories about other families from Bosnia, who were picked up at night by the police and brought to the airport. My parents thought, âwe already had to run from our country; we wonât allow our children to re-experience the same thing. They want us to leave, we will leave.â

It was a disaster when we got back. There was such a contrast to Germany. The war had only ended two years before. Everything had been destroyed in the country. Nobody had money. Everybody was very hostile, especially to people like us who had spent the war in safety. When I was in Germany, I always thought: âOk, here, I am someone from another country, but when I go back, it will be home. Theyâll welcome us as Bosnian people.â But it was way worse than it was here.

I finished school in Bosnia, and then I returned to Germany three and a half years ago. I got a scholarship, and I started my Masters in the department of clinical psychology and psychotherapy at TU Dresden. In the second semester of my Masters, the huge wave of refugees started coming to Germany. Being a refugee myself, I really had the urge to do something, to help the people arriving, but I wanted to do so by implementing my psychology skills. Even though I was only three years old at the time, I can remember really well how my parents struggled when they came to Germany. Initially, you are relieved because you are in a safe place. You are away from the bombs and the war. But when you come here, you donât know anybody, you donât know the language. You donât have the resources to accomplish to your goals.

Thatâs how we came up with the idea to set up companionships between refugees and students of psychology in their post-graduate studies. The main idea is to help the refugees find positive and meaningful activities. Things like a lack of meaningful activities are called âpost-migration stressors.â When refugees have activities and ways to accomplish their goals, their mental states really improve. Otherwise, these stressors can result in a downward spiral that leads to a depressive state.

"I have lived alone for two years. Before that, starting when I was fourteen, I lived in a youth welfare home for some years. My mother wasnât able to take care of me. I never got to know my father.

And I think my third big turning point was when I passed tenth grade. It probably doesnât sound especially ambitious, but for me as someone who skipped school for years and had terrible grades, it was one of my biggest achievements.

At this point, I have been successful in getting into the twelfth grade â I donât know how. I am in a happy relationship. I am doing better psychologically. I am happy. Through Fridays for Future, and a couple of other projects, I have found meaning in life, my place in society. I found what I want to do, that I like to help people, be active, organize things, and just be there for people who havenât had as much luck as I and who are currently in more difficult situations than I.

Now, I want to graduate twelfth grade. Then I would like to do a social program abroad for a year, hopefully in a childrenâs hospital, and help people with art therapy or other therapies, because I have realized that it can make a big difference. For me personally, it was a very big learning experience. I am incredibly happy that we have now made our way into the middle of society and that we get a lot of support, that a lot of people agree with us and listen to us, are behind us, and go out on the streets with us. I am also incredibly happy that we can position oursleves as Fridays for Future against the rightwing, against facism, against hate and say, âPeople can have their own opinions, but this is not an opinion. "I am from Dresden; I was born and raised here. I do like Dresden - especially in visual terms. I like the Elbe, the Elbe meadows. I didn't used to be that interested in the Altstadt. Now I find it quite beautiful.
But that's also just a little bit of Dresden. It's also a lot about people. Dresden has polarized lately with a certain kind of people, which you can perhaps group together. I think it's very inward-looking and older in terms of its inhabitants. I think the young people are just working their way into having more of a voice. I don't think there's a lot of consideration given to young people in general.

I hope that people will become a little more broad-minded, that certain social issues will be more internalized or even disseminated, that people will look out for each other more, that people will try to prevent violent situations, and that people will also show understanding for people they don't understand. We live in the land of ignorance. I have the feeling that people are increasingly moving through the world in a straight line, as if with tunnel vision, that they don't look to the left, to the right, up and down, but that they know they have a goal and that's where they have to go. Many things are accepted or completely ignored.

For example, when it comes to people on the street begging for money. I've heard things from my mother before like, "The begging mafia, you'd better not give them anything." I think a lot of it is just complete nonsense. People may not have wanted to accept the help. They are definitely there for some reason and should not to be ignored. But for many people it is quite uncomfortable to be approached, to deal with strangers. I think many people are afraid of strangers. People don't talk to each other. Especially now, with the pandemic, I have the impression that people have become very wary of contact. I think that in general people often think that someone is else is taking care of it. You can actually apply that to almost everything. And in the end, it doesn't get done and you only realize later that nobody did it."

"Wir sind vom Umweltzentrum und machen diese ABC-Tische seit ungefÃ¤hr einem Jahr. Wir haben auf der Bremer StraÃe angefangen. Letzten Sommer haben sie da ein Lager mit 1.000 Leuten aufgemacht. Es war heiÃ und es gab keinen Schatten. GegenÃ¼ber auf der anderen StraÃenseite gibt es einen Friedhof, der uns gehÃ¶rt. Den haben wir fÃ¼r die FlÃ¼chtlinge aufgemacht. Zuerst wollten wir dort gar nichts weiter machen, nur dass sie es als Park benutzen kÃ¶nnen. Aber dann haben wir einen Zettel aufgehÃ¤ngt und ehrenamtliche Deutschlehrer gesucht, und viele Leute sind hingekommen.

Damals kamen die Leute alle neu nach Dresden und wussten eigentlich gar nichts Ã¼ber die Stadt. Uns ging es darum, ganz praktische Dinge zu erklÃ¤ren, Stadtplan, StraÃenbahn und so was. Das Niveau bei den Tischen war sehr niedrig, es ging mehr darum, dass sie erst mal ankommen, ein bisschen Ruhe haben, erste WÃ¶rter lernen, erstmal Zeit haben nach der Flucht, nach der lange Route. Die hatten schon viel hinter sich. Am Anfang war das wichtigste gar nicht die Sprache, das wichtigste war, dass es Leute gibt, die sagen, es ist ok, ihr seid hier sicher. Damals gab es auch diese Nazis auf der Bremer StraÃe, das war auch ein bisschen kompliziert, damit umzugehen. Die Idee von den ABC-Tischen war mehr ein erster Zentimeter Zuversicht, dass es irgendwie geht."

UrsprÃ¼nglich gepostet am 12.07.2016
--
"We are from the Environment Center, and we have been doing these ABC tables for about a year. We started on Bremer street. Last summer, they opened a camp there with a 1,000 people. It was hot, and there wasn't any shade. Across the street, there is a graveyard that belongs to us. We opened it up for the refugees. First, we didn't want to do anything else, only let them use it as a park. But then we hung up a notice and looked for volunteer German teachers, and a lot of people came.

Back then, all the people were new to Dresden and didn't actually know anything about the city. We were just trying to explain really practical things, maps, trams, etc. The level of German at the tables was really low, it was more about that they first get adjusted, have a little peace, learn their first words in German -- just having some time after fleeing, after the long route. They already had so much behind them. At the beginning, the most important thing wasn't the language at all but that there were people, who said, it is ok, you are safe here. At the time, there were also these Nazis on Bremer street, which was also a little complicated to deal with. The idea of the ABC tables was more as a first centimeter of confidence, that it would somehow work out."

Ich hatte keine Papiere, weil ich in Tschechien gelebt habe.Ich hatte schon vorher Kontakt mit Sorben; sie haben mich eingeladen, nach Deutschland zu kommen. Ich war Lehrer im sorbischen Gymnasium und habe Tschechisch und FranzÃ¶sisch unterrichtet. Von der Ausbildung her bin ich eigentlich Politologe und Ãkonom.

2005 habe ich endlich meine Aufenthaltserlaubnis fÃ¼r hier bekommen. Es war sehr, sehr, sehr schwer. Es war auch schwer, die deutsche Sprache zu lernen. Ich hatte keinen Deutschkurs. Meiner Meinung nach ist die Situation jetzt aber besser als vor 20, 30 Jahren. Als ich hierher gekommen bin, haben uns Leute auf der Prager StraÃe angegriffen. Alle haben zugesehen. Eine einzige Person hat gesagt: âWas machst du da?â Er hat mein Leben gerettet. Trotzdem habe ich mich entschieden, in Deutschland und in Dresden zu bleiben. Ich habe schon viele LÃ¤nder gesehen - Deutschland hat sich zum Positiven verÃ¤ndert, besonders in Dresden. Ich lebe hier in der Neustadt. Ich habe schon von vielen Dingen gehÃ¶rt, aber mir ist nichts passiert. Ich lebe sehr gut hier. Es ist eine sehr gute Nachbarschaft. Leute, die ich nicht kenne, grÃ¼Ãen mich auf der StraÃe.

Positiv ist auch, dass Dresden International geworden ist, dass die Leute mehr lÃ¤cheln. Es gibt jetzt die MÃ¶glichkeit, Deutsch zu lernen. Ich bin traurig, dass ich diese MÃ¶glichkeit nicht richtig gehabt habe. Am Anfang waren die jungen Leute sehr aggressiv. Jetzt sehe ich in Dresden verschiedene Hautfarben. --
"I am from Madagascar. I have been in Dresden since 2013. Before that, I lived in the Lausitz. I came to Germany after the reunification. I didnât have any papers because was living in the Czech Republic. I had had contact with Sorbs; they invited me to come to Germany. I was teacher in a Sorbian high school, where I taught Czech and French. In terms of my education, I am actually a political scientist and economist.

In 2005, I finally got my German residence permit. It was very, very, very hard. It was also hard to learn German. I didnât have a German course. In my opinion, the situation is nevertheless better than it was 20 or 30 years ago. When I came here, people on Prager StraÃe attacked us. Everyone saw. One single person said, âWhat are you doing there?â He saved my life. Nevertheless, I decided to stay in Germany and in Dresden. I have already seen a lot of countries â Germany has changed in a positive direction, especially in Dresden. I live here in the Neustadt. I have heard about a lot of things, but nothing has happened to me. I live here really well. It is a really good neighborhood. People I donât know say hi to me on the street.

At first, the young people were really aggressive. Now, I see different skin colors in Dresden. It is also mixed in Madagascar. I like it a lot now. Even when these Monday demonstrations are good for our image, I think that is only one episode."

Und weil ich seit der Wende immer schon mal in Dresden zu Gast war und Dresden sehr toll finde, habe ich das gemacht. Ich bin also aus dem Ruhrgebiet hierher gezogen. Das hat mir bis jetzt immer noch nicht leid getan, obwohl meine Freunde, Familie, Kollegen, alle gesagt haben: âDas kannst du doch nicht machen!â Aber immer, wenn ich dann wieder im Ruhrgebiet zu Besuch bin und auf dem RÃ¼ckweg im Zug sitze, denke ich: So, jetzt fahre ich nach Hause. Es ist mein Zuhause geworden.

Nicht lange nachdem ich hierher gezogen bin, habe ich erfahren, dass die Aktion âLesestark!â immer Lesepaten sucht das. Also habe ich mich gemeldet. Seitdem gehe ich einmal im Monat in einen Kindergarten und lese vor. Das macht sehr viel SpaÃ. Die Kinder freuen sich immer, wenn ich komme. Ich lese Ihnen vor und habe auch immer etwas zum Basteln dabei. Manchmal sind wir auch hier in der BÃ¼cherei. Die Kinder kÃ¶nnen an die Regale und ich lese vor. Sie haben viel Zeit zu schnÃ¼ffeln und zu stÃ¶bern, und man kann sich eine BÃ¼cherkiste liefern lassen. Es ist schon toll, was hier passiert.

Bei den Lesepaten sind auch junge Leute dabei, aber es ist natÃ¼rlich eher die Ã¤ltere Klientel, weil man die Zeit mehr hat. Und viele MÃ¤nner fehlen- es sind doch oft Frauen. Von der Organisation âLesestark!â passiert ganz viel. Letzte Woche war wieder Fortbildung. Da werden Neuerscheinungen vorgestellt, dann gibt es eine Weihnachtsfeier, oder wir waren eingeladen zu âDie Weihnachtsgans Augusteâ im Kulturpalast. Es ist schÃ¶n, wenn ich bei diesen Veranstaltungen die anderen Lesepaten treffe. Man kann sich austauschen, man hat sich was zu erzÃ¤hlen.

Ich war frÃ¼her Grundschullehrerin. Ich habe meinen SchÃ¼lern auch immer vorgelesen. Wir hatten immer montags morgens einen Kreis. Ich habe es immer schon alles sehr wichtig erachtet, dass man Kindern vorliest, auch meinen eigenen Kindern, jetzt meinen Enkelkindern. Ich merke, dass Kinder interessiert sind. Es gab mal eine Zeit, als gesagt wurde, das hat sich bald Ã¼berlebt mit den BÃ¼chern, es liest keiner mehr, die haben alle einen Tablet oder sehen fern. Ich treffe ja nicht alle Schichten, aber die Menschen, mit denen ich BerÃ¼hrungspunkte habe, die lesen, die Kinder sind interessiert an BÃ¼chern. Ich denke, manche wird man nicht erreichen, das muss man auch klar sehen, weil die nicht zu solchen Veranstaltungen kommen, weil die nicht mit ihren Kindern in die BÃ¼cherei gehen, sondern lieber die Kinder vor der Glotze parken. Man kann eben keinen zwingen, herzukommen. Aber bei den Anlaufstellen, die ich habe, haben BÃ¼cher noch eine wichtige Rolle, und das freut mich ."

UrsprÃ¼nglich gepostet am 07.12.20219
--
"I have now been in Dresden for seven years. My daughter studied here and told me at some point that I was going to be a grandma and asked if I could imagine moving to Dresden. And because I had always been a tourist in Dresden since the reunification and thought Dresden was great, I did it. I moved here from the Ruhrgebiet. I have never been sorry, although my friends, family, colleagues all said, âYou canât do it!â But always when I visit the Ruhrgebiet, and I am on my way back, I think âSo, now I am going home.â Itâs become my home.

Not long after I moved here, I learned that the project âLesestark!â was looking for reading mentors. So, I got in touch. Since then, I go to a kindergarten once a month and read to the children. Itâs a lot of fun. The children are always happy when I come. I read to them, and I always have some crafts with me. Sometimes, we are also in the library. The children can go look through the shelves, and I read aloud. They have a lot of time to look around, and you can have a book box delivered. What happens here is great.

There are some young people who are reading mentors, but itâs mostly older people, because we have the time. And there arenât too many men â itâs often women. The organization âLesestark!â does a lot. Last week was another training session. New publications are introduced, then there is a Christmas party, and we were invited to âThe Christmas Goose Augusteâ in the Kulturpalast. Itâs nice to meet the other mentors at these events. You can talk to each other; you have a lot to tell.

I used to be a grade school teacher. I always read to my students . We always had a circle on Monday mornings. I thought it was really important to read to children, also my own children, and now my grandchildren. I notice that children are interested. There was a time when everyone was saying that books have run their course, no one reads any more, they all have a tablet or watch TV. I donât meet people from all classes, but the people with whom I have contact read; the children are interested in books. I think that you wonât reach some people, but you have to recognize that, because they donât come to events like these, because they donât bring their children to the library, but just stick them in front of the TV. You canât force anyone to come here. But in the places I go, books still play an important role, and that makes me happy."

Originally posted on 12/07/2019

media.description:
âIch arbeite beim Panometer. In Dresden-Reick gibt es dieses alte Gasometer, in dem riesige Panoramen ausgestellt werden. Es ist eine sehr emotionale Variante, wie man Geschichte auch vermitteln kann. Wir als Betreiber haben die Erfahrung gemacht, egal wem wir das zeigen, ob Kindergartenkindern oder emeritierten Professoren, jeder nimmt was anderes raus. Das Kind sieht natÃ¼rlich etwas komplett anderes, ist begeistert von Objekten oder Dingen, die es da erkennen kann, wÃ¤hrend der Professor natÃ¼rlich die ZusammenhÃ¤nge erkennt und ganz andere SchlÃ¼sse daraus ziehen kann. Das ist eine sehr intelligente Art der Wissensvermittlung.

Das Besondere in Dresden ist, dass es zwei Panoramen gibt, die sich immer abwechseln, einmal Dresden im Barock und dann Dresden 1945. Dresden im Barock zeigt das augusteische Zeitalter, also das wofÃ¼r Dresden ein StÃ¼ck weit steht beziehungsweise wie sich Dresden selbst gern sieht oder wie es sich touristisch vermarktet. Dresden 1945 ist eigentlich das Gegenteil. Das ist ein sehr prÃ¤sentes Thema in der Stadt und eigentlich der Tiefpunkt, als diese barocke Pracht und der GroÃteil der Fassaden zerstÃ¶rt wurden. Man muss die beiden Panoramen im Zusammenhang betrachten, um die Stadt besser zu verstehen.

In dem Panorama von 1945 sieht man eine Momentaufnahme nach den schweren Bombenangriffen. Man sieht die GroÃflÃ¤chigkeit der ZerstÃ¶rung. Man erkennt, wie punktuell nur noch alte Strukturen vorhanden sind und wie groÃflÃ¤chig nach der ZerstÃ¶rung umgestaltet wurde. Diese gewachsene europÃ¤ische Stadt existiert in dem Sinne nicht mehr. Ein Viertel wurde jetzt neu rekonstruiert, aber da sieht man natÃ¼rlich, dass das neue Fassaden sind. Es dauert vielleicht 100 oder 150 Jahre, bis sich da eine gewisse Patina bildet.

Zum Panorama gibt es auch immer eine Begleitausstellung, die thematisiert, wie es dazu gekommen ist. Es sind einige interessante Punkte, die man nicht vergessen sollte, wenn man darÃ¼ber spricht. Dresden war bei vielen Sachen ganz vorn mit dabei. Hier fanden zum Beispiel die ersten BÃ¼cherverbrennungen statt. Hier gab es im Rathaus auch so eine Art VorlÃ¤uferausstellung zur groÃen Ausstellung âEntartete Kunstâ. Und es gab natÃ¼rlich viele Angriffe, die von Deutschland ausgegangen sind.

Dass das natÃ¼rlich am Ende zurÃ¼ckkommt, sollte nicht verwundern. An sich ist es ja nur konsequent. Beziehungsweise finde ich es etwas Ã¼berflÃ¼ssig, im Krieg nach Regeln zu fragen. Man kann einen Krieg mit Regeln machen - es gab die Kabinettskriege im 18. Jahrhundert, wo zwei ebenbÃ¼rtige Herrscher versucht haben, sich mit ihren Armeen auszumanÃ¶vrieren und dabei die eingesetzten Mittel nach MÃ¶glichkeit zu begrenzen -, aber sobald eine gewisse Grenze Ã¼berschritten ist - das sieht man im DreiÃigjÃ¤hrigen Krieg oder noch viel besser bei den Kriegen im 19. und 20. Jahrhundert - da wird nicht gefragt, darf ich das jetzt oder darf ich das nicht, sondern da wird einfach gemacht, um zu gewinnen. Ich glaube, es sollte jedem klar sein, dass, wenn so etwas einmal entfesselt ist, dass man dann nur Fersengeld geben kann, wenn einem sein Leben lieb ist.â

UrsprÃ¼nglich am 27.02.2019 gepostet
--
âI work at the Panometer. In Dresden-Reick, there is old gasometer in which giant panoramas are displayed. It is a very emotional way of conveying history. As the operators, we have had the experience that no matter who we show it to, whether kindergarteners or emeritus professors, everyone gets something out of it. The child will of course see something completely different, is excited about objects and things, which he or she can recognize, while the professor sees the connections and draws other conclusions out of it. Itâs a very intelligent way of conveying information.

The special thing about Dresden is that there are two panoramas, which always alternate â Dresden in the Baroque period and then Dresden 1945. Dresden in the Baroque period shows the August the Strong era â so what Dresden stands for or what Dresden likes to think of itself or market itself. Dresden 1945 is actually the opposite. It is a very current subject in the city and actually the low point when all the baroque finery and the majority of the facades were destroyed. You have to see both panoramas in connection in order to understand the city better.

In the panorama of 1945, you see a snapshot after the heavy bombing. You see the large scale of the destruction. You realize how selectively only a few old structures survived and how large-scale the reshaping of the city was after the destruction. This evolved European city doesnât exist in that sense anymore. An area is now reconstructed but you see of course that they are new facades. It will take maybe 100 or 150 years until they have a certain patina.

In the Panorama, there is always also an accompanying exhibition that thematizes how it came to that. There are some interesting points that you should not forget if you talk about it. Dresden was involved in a lot of things from the start. The first book burnings took place here. Here in the city hall, there was a kind of precursor exhibition to the âDegenerate Artâ exhibition. And there were of course many attacks that came from Germany.

Of course, it shouldnât be surprising that the attacks were returned in the end. It just follows. I think itâs somewhat superfluous to ask about rules during a war. You can conduct war with rules â there were the Cabinet Wars in the 18th century, where two rulers of noble birth tried to outmaneuver each other and thereby limit the employed means as far as possible â but as soon as a certain boundary is passed, you see it in the Thirty Years War or much better in the wars of the 19th and 20th century, no one asks, âMay I now? Es ist eine sehr emotionale Variante, wie man Geschichte auch vermitteln kann. Wir als Betreiber haben die Erfahrung gemacht, egal wem wir das zeigen, ob Kindergartenkindern oder emeritierten Professoren, jeder nimmt was anderes raus. Das Kind sieht natÃ¼rlich etwas komplett anderes, ist begeistert von Objekten oder Dingen, die es da erkennen kann, wÃ¤hrend der Professor natÃ¼rlich die ZusammenhÃ¤nge erkennt und ganz andere SchlÃ¼sse daraus ziehen kann. Das ist eine sehr intelligente Art der Wissensvermittlung.

Das Besondere in Dresden ist, dass es zwei Panoramen gibt, die sich immer abwechseln, einmal Dresden im Barock und dann Dresden 1945. Dresden im Barock zeigt das augusteische Zeitalter, also das wofÃ¼r Dresden ein StÃ¼ck weit steht beziehungsweise wie sich Dresden selbst gern sieht oder wie es sich touristisch vermarktet. Dresden 1945 ist eigentlich das Gegenteil. Das ist ein sehr prÃ¤sentes Thema in der Stadt und eigentlich der Tiefpunkt, als diese barocke Pracht und der GroÃteil der Fassaden zerstÃ¶rt wurden. Man muss die beiden Panoramen im Zusammenhang betrachten, um die Stadt besser zu verstehen.

In dem Panorama von 1945 sieht man eine Momentaufnahme nach den schweren Bombenangriffen. Man sieht die GroÃflÃ¤chigkeit der ZerstÃ¶rung. Man erkennt, wie punktuell nur noch alte Strukturen vorhanden sind und wie groÃflÃ¤chig nach der ZerstÃ¶rung umgestaltet wurde. Diese gewachsene europÃ¤ische Stadt existiert in dem Sinne nicht mehr. Ein Viertel wurde jetzt neu rekonstruiert, aber da sieht man natÃ¼rlich, dass das neue Fassaden sind. Es dauert vielleicht 100 oder 150 Jahre, bis sich da eine gewisse Patina bildet.

Zum Panorama gibt es auch immer eine Begleitausstellung, die thematisiert, wie es dazu gekommen ist. Es sind einige interessante Punkte, die man nicht vergessen sollte, wenn man darÃ¼ber spricht. Dresden war bei vielen Sachen ganz vorn mit dabei. Hier fanden zum Beispiel die ersten BÃ¼cherverbrennungen statt. Hier gab es im Rathaus auch so eine Art VorlÃ¤uferausstellung zur groÃen Ausstellung âEntartete Kunstâ. Und es gab natÃ¼rlich viele Angriffe, die von Deutschland ausgegangen sind.

Dass das natÃ¼rlich am Ende zurÃ¼ckkommt, sollte nicht verwundern. An sich ist es ja nur konsequent. Beziehungsweise finde ich es etwas Ã¼berflÃ¼ssig, im Krieg nach Regeln zu fragen. Jahrhundert, wo zwei ebenbÃ¼rtige Herrscher versucht haben, sich mit ihren Armeen auszumanÃ¶vrieren und dabei die eingesetzten Mittel nach MÃ¶glichkeit zu begrenzen -, aber sobald eine gewisse Grenze Ã¼berschritten ist - das sieht man im DreiÃigjÃ¤hrigen Krieg oder noch viel besser bei den Kriegen im 19. und 20. âI work at the Panometer. In Dresden-Reick, there is old gasometer in which giant panoramas are displayed. It is a very emotional way of conveying history. As the operators, we have had the experience that no matter who we show it to, whether kindergarteners or emeritus professors, everyone gets something out of it. The child will of course see something completely different, is excited about objects and things, which he or she can recognize, while the professor sees the connections and draws other conclusions out of it. Itâs a very intelligent way of conveying information.

The special thing about Dresden is that there are two panoramas, which always alternate â Dresden in the Baroque period and then Dresden 1945. Dresden in the Baroque period shows the August the Strong era â so what Dresden stands for or what Dresden likes to think of itself or market itself. Dresden 1945 is actually the opposite. It is a very current subject in the city and actually the low point when all the baroque finery and the majority of the facades were destroyed. You have to see both panoramas in connection in order to understand the city better.

In the panorama of 1945, you see a snapshot after the heavy bombing. You see the large scale of the destruction. You realize how selectively only a few old structures survived and how large-scale the reshaping of the city was after the destruction. This evolved European city doesnât exist in that sense anymore. An area is now reconstructed but you see of course that they are new facades. It will take maybe 100 or 150 years until they have a certain patina.

In the Panorama, there is always also an accompanying exhibition that thematizes how it came to that. There are some interesting points that you should not forget if you talk about it. Dresden was involved in a lot of things from the start. The first book burnings took place here. Here in the city hall, there was a kind of precursor exhibition to the âDegenerate Artâ exhibition. And there were of course many attacks that came from Germany.

Of course, it shouldnât be surprising that the attacks were returned in the end. It just follows. I think itâs somewhat superfluous to ask about rules during a war. You can conduct war with rules â there were the Cabinet Wars in the 18th century, where two rulers of noble birth tried to outmaneuver each other and thereby limit the employed means as far as possible â but as soon as a certain boundary is passed, you see it in the Thirty Years War or much better in the wars of the 19th and 20th century, no one asks, âMay I now? Or may I not?â Instead, things are just done to win. I think it should be clear to everyone that once something like that is unleashed, the only thing you can do is run away if you want to live.â

Or the rules and social legislation or integration into the job market â someone who speaks German as a second language canât deal with it themselves.

"I am 21 years old. I finished my bachelor studies in the department of geography and geoinformatics in Minsk, the capital of the Republic of Belarus. Before I tell my personal story, I would like to describe the situation in our country. Our country has long been called the last dictatorship in Europe, and this is true, but the last year has exceeded all expectations. First of all, competent candidates were not allowed to run in the elections in the summer of 2020. All of them were put in jail. Rallies against this were broken up in many cities, especially in the capital. At that time, the first brutal attacks by riot police occurred. They all wore black masks, walked around without identifying themselves, and just beat people. I was also on the street at that time and experienced the police violence and arbitrariness.

After 14.07.2020, when the presidential candidates were not registered, I was arrested and taken to a police station. There, a detention record was made against me, but no crime record. Fortunately, I was released. However, they then sent me the protocol and a summons to appear in court. At the same time, I was summoned by phone to the office of the Investigative Committee for Minsk as a witness in a criminal case. It was about violently resisting law enforcement officers and active participation and organization of mass disturbances. The whole process was connected with the first confrontation with riot police in Victory Square.

On July 27, my best friend was arrested. He was recently sentenced to four years in prison after being found guilty of the above. In my case, fortunately, I was only fined.

From the moment of my arrest, my face as well as fingerprints were in the database of the Ministry of Interior. Nevertheless, I participated in all subsequent protests and was registered as an observer for the elections on August 9. However, I was not allowed to enter the polling station in my hometown of Molodechno to vote.It is also important to mention that my calls were tapped, there were long delays before I could make calls, the internet was regularly blocked. This is how my friend was caught; his cell phone number was monitored and the interception took place when he went to a store.

After that, I continued to participate in all the protests, especially on August 9, 10, and 11, the day of the most severe clashes with stun grenades, tear gas and rubber bullets, and weapons. I carried bandages, hydrogen peroxide and antiseptic in case I or my friends were injured. I pasted and distributed leaflets that contained real information about what was happening. At that time, I was also still employed at the Department of Geography and Geoinformatics at the state university.

During the same period, I underwent a medical examination at the Military Registration and Conscription Office, following the results of which I was sent for surgery for varicocele. Unfortunately, the rehabilitation period did not go smoothly, because I had to take care of my grandfather. During this time, I was called by the local police department who tried to invite me for a "preventive interview". I politely declined the invitation, citing my sick leave. After two weeks, I fell ill with coronavirus, which also allowed me to refuse calls to visit local Interior Ministry officials. However, it did not stop the local district official from coming to my home. He urged me to sign a paper stating that my actions aimed at calling for illegal events or further participation will result in criminal liability under the article on extremism. I refused to sign."

It was industrial animal production, and I didn't like it at all. Animal welfare was not a big issue, it was all about production.

But I finished that. Then the Wall came down in 1989. I trained to be a 3-D computer animator. I met an American man and then we both found jobs in computer animation and moved to London. When I was still living in Berlin, I was on vacation in South Africa. There I met a South African man and totally fell in love with the country. In London I got together with the South African man and moved to South Africa. I no longer saw any point in my job and just wanted to live a healthy, good life in the country, as a self-sufficient person. I thought South Africa was the best place to do that - who knew what was happening here in Europe with war and whatever. I wanted to get away and live in the country.

That's what I did for a few years. I gave birth to my children there, all at home without a doctor, in a teepee, in the water. That was a wonderful experience. Then I separated from the father of my children. At some point I also had to go back to work after the money I had saved ran out. I did a lot of things down there - I sold food at the market, I set up a farmer's market myself, I ran a guesthouse once - but at some point I had to start earning real money again. I then moved to Cape Town and worked in the call center there.

My children grew up. I wanted them to go to university and to get to know Europe. It was beautiful down there, but financially it was very difficult for me. The situation in the country was also getting more and more uncomfortable. There was more and more crime. You couldn't really feel safe anymore. That's why I decided to return to Dresden with the children. Also my parents were always complaining that I wasn't there. 

My daughter was seventeen, my son fifteen, when we came back in 2017. They didn't speak German. They really wanted to go to the International School or they wouldn't have come. Only English was spoken there, too; that's why my son still doesn't really speak German. My daughter didn't last long here. She was cut off from her friends, then the weather and the people - people in South Africa are much friendlier and laugh more, are more cordial and open. She found it very hard here and went back to South Africa."

Das war unter meinem Niveau, aber es hat mir SpaÃ gemacht. Dann habe ich zwei Jahre eine Ausbildung im Innenausbau gemacht. Ich war der beste im Kurs, weil ich das wollte. Es hat mir SpaÃ gemacht. Wenn die Arbeit SpaÃ macht, dann kann man das zur Perfektion treiben. Und ich bin Perfektionist.

Ich habe die Frauenkirche innen mit gebaut, weil ich ein Perfektionist bin. Ich habe dort Brandschutz gebaut; als Muster. Dann kamen die Leute mit einem Messschieber und haben auf den Zehntelmillimeter gemessen, ob das passt. Und es hat gepasst. Da war ich vierzig. Dann dachte ich mir, was kommt jetzt danach, noch etwas Besseres? Ich habe in Bad Homburg eine Wand gebaut, 12 Meter hoch, 17 Meter breit, vier Wellen Ã¼bereinander. Toleranz 0. Eigentlich geht das nicht. Das sind 6-Millimeter-Gipskartonplatten, die muss man biegen, anschrauben, spachteln, und dann kam Kirschfurnier drauf. Wenn man ungenau baut, werden die SpaltmaÃe immer grÃ¶Ãer.

Ich habe immer gesagt, man muss sich damit beschÃ¤ftigen, dann kann man das machen. Wenn man gut ist, wird das, was man anfasst, zu Gold. Das hat auf dem Bau wunderbar funktioniert. Dann habe ich gebaut; ich hatte immer Arbeit, sechs Jahre lang. Dann hat mich eine Dresdner Firma beschissen. Die haben mich nicht bezahlt. Das ging bis vor Gericht und dann ist die Firma insolvent gegangen. Ich habe kein Geld gesehen. Ich habe ein halbes Jahr umsonst gearbeitet. Das hat mir dann keinen SpaÃ mehr gemacht. Wenn etwas keinen SpaÃ macht, hÃ¶re ich auf. Und dann habe ich Probleme mit dem RÃ¼cken gehabt durch das schwere Arbeiten."

Teil 1/2
--
"I have a very eventful past. I have moved around a lot. However, I have lived here in Dresden for the longest time. As a child, I lived in Moscow for four years. My father studied there; he was in the military. I wanted to be in the military, too. My parents forbade me to do so, but I really wanted to. Then I wasn't allowed to study it, and I had to do something else. Things take their course - you always do something, even though you don't want to.

I was eventually in the military, too; ten years as a professional soldier. I lived in the forest for a long time. An order came: " Drive out, don't ask any questions, no food for three days!" - No problem.

When the NVA collapsed with the Wende, I worked as a salesman. There was no continuing education at that time. I sold old cars, I sold furniture, I sold carpets. Then I went into construction as a qualified engineer and plastered holes in the cellar. That was below my skill level, but I enjoyed it. Then I did an apprenticeship in interior design for two years. I was the best in the class because that's what I wanted to do. It was fun for me. If the work is fun, then you can push it to perfection. And I am a perfectionist.

I helped build the inside of the Frauenkirche because I'm a perfectionist. I built structural fire protection there; as a prototype. Then people came with calipers and measured to the tenth of a millimeter to see if it would fit. And it did fit. I was forty then. Then I thought to myself, what comes next, something even better? I built a wall in Bad Homburg, 12 meters high, 17 meters wide, four layers on top of each other. Tolerance 0. Actually, it' s not possible. These are 6-millimeter gypsum plasterboard panels that have to be bent, screwed on, filled, and then cherry veneer was put on top. If you build imprecisely, the gaps get bigger and bigger.

I always said, you have to work at it, then you can do it. If you're good, what you touch turns to gold. That worked wonderfully in construction. Then I built; I always had work, for six years. Then a Dresden company screwed me over. They didn't pay me. That went all the way to court and then the company went bankrupt. I didn't see any money. I worked for free for half a year. I didn't enjoy it anymore. When something isn't fun, I quit. And then I had problems with my back because of the heavy work."

Part 1/2

"Ich lebe gerne in Dresden. Ich hÃ¤tte nie gedacht, dass ich als PreuÃe bei den Sachsen mal glÃ¼cklich bin, aber es ist eine wunderschÃ¶ne Stadt. Hier hat man eine sehr hohe LebensqualitÃ¤t, die aber noch bezahlbar ist. In anderen StÃ¤dten mÃ¼sste man sehr viel Geld fÃ¼r solche QualitÃ¤t hinlegen.

Ich habe eine Veranstaltungsagentur in Dresden. Wir machen die unter anderem die HOPE-Gala, die fÃ¼r viele Dresdner mittlerweile ein Begriff ist. Ich komme ursprÃ¼nglich aus Berlin und bin 2004 mit Sarrasani nach Dresden bekommen. Ich habe hier die Dinnershow mit aufgebaut. Seit 2009 bin ich Chefin von der Agentur. Dann habe ich immer nebenbei als Hostess gearbeitet. Ich habe immer SpaÃ daran gehabt, Leute zu begeistern, Ideen zu kreieren und auch umzusetzen. Viele sagen: âMensch, da verdient man doch kein Geld mit!â, aber ich habe gesagt, das was ich mache muss mir SpaÃ machen; wenn ein bisschen Geld hÃ¤ngen bleibt, wÃ¤re es natÃ¼rlich noch besser. Mittlerweile ist es auch so. Aber es gab Zeiten, da blieb kein Geld hÃ¤ngen, da hatte man nur SpaÃ. Aber trotzdem war immer was zu essen da; wir sind nicht verhungert. Man muss nur wissen wie und vor allem braucht man ein gutes Netzwerk, das auch hinter einem steht, wenn es einem schlecht geht. Auf der einen Seite â klar, die finanzielle UnterstÃ¼tzung durch die Bundesregierung, aber auf der anderen Seite â wenn du in der Zeit keine mentale StÃ¤rke hast, dann wird es schwer, jemals wieder das Leben zu fÃ¼hren, das man davor hatte. Aber ich habe immer Hoffnung, sonst ist das Leben nicht lebenswert."

"I like living in Dresden. I never thought that I would be happy as a Prussian with the Saxons, but it is a beautiful city. I have found many friends here, my family, my happiness. I can recommend Dresden to everyone, not just tourists, but also for living here. You have a very high quality of life, but it is still affordable. In other cities you would have to pay a lot of money for such quality.

I have an event agency in Dresden. Among other things, we do the HOPE Gala, which has become a familiar event for many Dresdeners. I originally come from Berlin and came to Dresden with Sarrasani in 2004. I helped to build up the dinner show here. Since 2009, I have been the boss of the agency. We do a lot of nice events in this great city.

Nothing was ever planned in my life. I am actually a primary school teacher. I did my training in the GDR, but it was not accredited. Then I worked as a hostess on the side. I've always enjoyed inspiring people, creating ideas and putting them into practice. Ten years at Sarrasani was a very, very good school for everything that came after in my life. I'm a gut person, and if my gut says it's right, then I do it. Many people would say: "Man, you don't earn any money with that!", but I said that what I do has to be fun for me; if there's a little money in it, it is even better. At this point, it is the case. But there were times when there was no money, just fun. But there was always something to eat; we didn't starve. You just have to know how and, above all, you need a good network that stands behind you even when things are going badly. I think that was also very, very important in Corona times, because otherwise many people would simply have fallen by the wayside. On the one hand - of course, the financial support from the federal government, but on the other hand - if you don't have mental strength during that time, then it's hard to return to the life you had before. But I always have hope, otherwise life is not worth living."
